00:14:22.940 | All the other experiences I had with programming was I'd spend hours typing something in.

00:16:11.220 | And PHP was when I finally got it.
00:16:13.860 | When it finally clicked.
00:16:16.140 | And then all of that stuff started to make sense enough to me that I thought, I can do this.
00:16:25.900 | So would it be fair to say that we wouldn't have DHH without PHP and therefore you owe all your success to PHP?
00:16:33.520 | A hundred percent that's true.
00:16:34.760 | And it's even better than that because PHP to me didn't just give me a start in terms of making my own web applications.
00:16:42.300 | It actually gave me a bar.
00:16:44.260 | In many ways, I think the pinnacle of web developer ergonomics is late 90s PHP.
00:16:52.220 | You write this script, you FTP it to a server, and instantly it's deployed.
00:16:58.160 | Instantly it's available.
00:16:59.580 | You change anything in that file and you reload.
00:17:02.180 | Boom.
00:17:02.620 | It's right there.
00:17:03.180 | There's no web servers.
00:17:04.740 | There's no setup.
00:17:06.420 | There's just an Apache that runs ModPHP.
00:17:09.920 | And it was essentially the easiest way to get a dynamic web page up and going.
00:17:14.660 | And this is one of the things I've been chasing that high for basically the rest of my career.
00:17:19.820 | That it was so easy to make things for the internet in the mid to late 90s.
00:17:25.540 | How did we lose the sensibilities that allowed us to not just work this way, but get new people into the industry to give them their success experiences?
00:17:36.060 | That I had adding a freaking blink tag to an HTML page, FTPing a PHP page to an Apache web server without knowing really anything about anything, without knowing anything about frameworks, without knowing anything about setup.
00:17:51.000 | All of that stuff have really taken us to a place where it sometimes feels like we're barely better off.
00:17:58.080 | Like webpages aren't that different from what they were in the late 90s, early 2000s.
00:18:03.320 | They're still just forms.
00:18:04.500 | They still just write to databases.
00:18:06.340 | A lot of people, I think, are very uncomfortable with the fact that they are essentially crud monkeys.
00:18:11.920 | They just make systems that create, read, update, or delete rows in a database.
00:18:18.320 | And they have to compensate for that existential dread by overcomplicating things.
00:18:24.920 | Now, that's a bit of a character.
00:18:26.280 | There's more to it.
00:18:27.160 | And there's things you can learn for more sophisticated ways of thinking about this.
00:18:30.540 | But there's still an ideal here, which is why I was so happy you had Peter Levels on, because he still basically works like this.
00:18:36.660 | And I look at that and go, man, that's amazing.
00:18:38.720 | Yeah, you're chasing that high.
00:18:40.280 | He's been high all along.
00:18:42.120 | Yes.
00:18:42.540 | Using PHP, jQuery, and SQLite.
00:18:47.540 | I think it's amazing because he's proving that this isn't just a nostalgic dream.
00:18:52.800 | He's actually doing it.
00:18:54.420 | He's running all these businesses.
00:18:55.780 | Now, some of that is, as he would admit up first, up front, is that he's just one guy.
00:19:02.280 | And you can do different things when you're just one guy.
00:19:04.760 | When you're working in a team, when I started working on a team, when I started working with Jason Freed on Basecamp, we at first didn't use version control together.
00:19:15.660 | I used version control for myself.
00:19:17.480 | And then I thought, you know what?
00:19:18.840 | Designers, they're probably not smart enough to figure out CBS.
00:19:23.360 | And therefore, I'm just like, no, no, no, you just FTP it up.
00:19:27.540 | You just FTP it.
00:19:28.420 | I knew they knew how to do FTP.
00:19:30.640 | And then after the third time I had overridden their changes, I was like, God damn it.
00:19:34.140 | I guess I got to teach Jason CBS to not do that again.
00:19:37.960 | But I think there's still way more truth to the fact that we can work the way we did in the 90s, work the way Peter works today, even in the team context.
00:19:49.360 | And that we've been far too willing to hand over far too much of our developer ergonomics to the merchants of complexity.
00:19:57.000 | And you've been chasing that with Rails 8.
00:19:59.840 | So how do you bring all the cool features of a modern framework and make it no build, make it as easy to create something and to ship it as it was in the 90s with just PHP?
00:20:13.080 | It's very difficult for me to beat the Peter Lovell's approach of just, it's so easy to just ship some PHP.
00:20:21.980 | And it should be.
00:20:23.080 | Why should it be harder than that?
00:20:24.940 | Our computers today are almost infinitely faster than what they were in the 90s.
00:20:30.500 | So shouldn't we be able to work in even easier ways?
00:20:33.800 | We should be looking back on the 90s and go like, oh, that was way too complicated.
00:20:37.780 | Now we have more sophisticated technology that's way faster and it allows us to work in these easier to use ways.
00:20:44.400 | But that's not true.
00:20:45.520 | But now you can see the line I draw in my work with Ruby and Rails and especially with Rails 8.
00:20:51.480 | No build to me is reaching back to that 90s feeling and going, now we can do some of those things without giving up on all the progress.
00:21:02.380 | Because I do think you can get too nostalgic.
00:21:04.220 | I do think you can start just fantasizing that everything was better in the 90s.
00:21:09.140 | It wasn't.
00:21:10.200 | I mean, I was there.
00:21:11.080 | There was a lot of things that sucked.
00:21:12.440 | And if we can somehow find a way to combine the advantages and advances we've had over the past 20 years with that ease of developer ergonomics, we can win.
00:21:23.780 | No build is a rejection of the part of web development I've hated the most in the past 10, 15 years, which is the JavaScript scene.
00:21:35.060 | And I don't say that as someone who hates JavaScript.
00:21:37.720 | I mean, I often joke that JavaScript is my second favorite programmer language.
00:21:41.760 | It's a very distant second.
00:21:43.180 | Ruby is by far and away number one.
00:21:45.300 | But I actually like JavaScript.
00:21:46.800 | I don't think it's a bad language.
00:21:49.020 | It gets a lot of flack.
00:21:51.040 | People add a string of two plus a one and it gives something nonsense.
00:21:55.280 | And I just go like, yeah, but why would you do that?
00:21:57.900 | Just don't do that.
00:21:58.600 | The language is actually quite lovely, especially the modern version.
00:22:02.340 | And ES6 that really introduced a proper class syntax to it so I could work with JavaScript in many of the same ways that I love working with Ruby made things so much better.
00:22:13.340 | But in the early 2010s until quite recently, all of that advancement happened in preprocessing, happened in built pipelines.
00:22:24.620 | The browsers couldn't speak a dialect of JavaScript that was pleasant to work with.
00:22:29.220 | So everyone started to precompiling their JavaScript to be able to use more modern ways of programming with a browser that was seen as stuck with an ancient version of JavaScript that no one actually wanted to work with.
00:22:42.340 | And that made sense to me, but it was also deeply unpleasant.
00:22:46.380 | And I remember thinking during that time, the dark ages, as I referred to them with JavaScript, that this cannot be the final destination.
00:22:55.440 | There's no way that we have managed to turn the internet into such an unpleasant place to work where I would start working on a project in JavaScript using Webpack and all of these dependencies.
00:23:09.380 | And I would put it down for literally five minutes and the thing wouldn't compile anymore.
00:23:13.660 | The amount of churn that the JavaScript community, especially with its frameworks and its tooling, went through in the decade from 2010 to 2020 was absurd.
00:23:24.900 | And you had to be trapped inside of that asylum to not realize what an utterly perverse situation we had landed ourselves in.
00:23:38.260 | Why does everything break all the time?
00:23:41.440 | I mean, the joke wouldn't be just that the software would break.
00:23:44.040 | That would annoy me personally.
00:23:45.140 | But then I'd go on Hacker News and I'd see some thread on the latest JavaScript release of some framework.
00:23:51.600 | And the thread would be like, someone would ask, well, aren't we using the thing we just used three months ago?
00:23:57.900 | And people would be like, that thing is so outdated.
00:24:00.060 | That's so three months ago.
00:24:02.060 | You got to get with the new program.
00:24:04.220 | We're completely rewriting everything for the oomph-teen time.
00:24:07.640 | And anything you've learned in the framework you've been spending the last amount of time on, it's all useless.
00:24:13.980 | You got to throw everything out and you got to start over.
00:24:16.080 | Why aren't you doing it, stupid idiot?
00:24:18.200 | Is that a kind of mass hysteria that took over the developer community, you think?
00:24:22.200 | Like where you have to keep creating new frameworks and new frameworks?
00:24:25.380 | And are we past that dark age?
00:24:28.880 | I think we're getting out of it.
00:24:30.860 | And we're getting out of it because browsers have gotten so much better.
00:24:35.260 | There was a stagnation in browser technology.
00:24:38.440 | Some of it was an overhang all the way back from IE5.
00:24:43.040 | So IE5 essentially put the whole internet development experience into a deep freeze because Microsoft won the browser wars in the mid-2000s.
00:24:52.680 | And then they basically disbanded their browser development team because they're like, all right, job done.
00:24:57.520 | We don't need any more innovation on the internet.
00:24:59.600 | Can we just go back to writing Windows forms or something now that we control everything?
00:25:03.840 | And it really wasn't until obviously Firefox kind of kindled a little bit of something, then Chrome got into the scene and Google got serious about moving the web forward.
00:25:15.740 | That you had a kindling of maybe the browser could be better.
00:25:20.480 | Maybe the browser wasn't frozen in time in 2005.
00:25:23.220 | Maybe the browser could actually evolve like the development platform that it is.
00:25:29.680 | But then what happened was you had a lot of smart people who poured in to the web because the web turned out to be the greatest application development platform of all time.
00:25:40.680 | This was where all the money was being made.
00:25:42.460 | This was where all the billionaires were being minted.
00:25:45.160 | This was where the Facebooks and whatever of the world came to be.
00:25:49.400 | So you had all of this brain power applied to the problem of how to work with the web.
00:25:55.500 | And there were some very smart people with some, I'm sure, very good ideas who did not have programmer happiness as their motivation number one.
00:26:08.400 | They had other priorities and those priorities allowed them to discount and even rationalize the complexity they were injecting everywhere.
00:26:20.320 | Some of that complexity came from organizational structure.
00:26:23.860 | When you have a company like Facebook, for example, that does depend on the web and want to push it forward,
00:26:28.480 | but have sliced the development role, job, into these tiny little niches.
00:26:35.160 | I'm a front-end glob pipeline configurator.
00:26:40.720 | Oh, yeah.
00:26:41.680 | Well, I'm a front-end whatever engineer.
00:26:44.220 | And suddenly the web developer was no longer one person.
00:26:48.100 | It was 15 different roles.
00:26:50.040 | That in itself injected a ton of complexity.
00:26:52.520 | But I also want to give it the bold case here, which was that some of the complexity was necessary to get to where we are today.
00:27:01.060 | That the complexity was a bridge.
00:27:03.420 | It wasn't the destination, but we had to cross that bridge to get to where we are today, where browsers are, frankly, incredible.
00:27:10.600 | The JavaScript you can write in a text file and then serve on a web server for a browser to ingest is amazing.
00:27:17.760 | It's actually a really good experience.
00:27:19.380 | You don't need any preprocessing.
00:27:20.760 | And you could just write text files, send them to a browser, and you have an incredible development.
00:27:25.540 | And we should also say that it can kind of be broken, at least the HTML, but even the JavaScript could be a little bit broken.
00:27:31.220 | And it kind of still works.
00:27:33.000 | Like maybe half-ass works, but like just the amount of mess, of smelly code that a browser has to deal with is insane.
00:27:43.860 | This is one of the hardest problems in computing today, is to parse the entire internet.
00:27:49.600 | Because thankfully for us as web developers, but perhaps not so much for the browser developers, every web page that has ever been created, minus the brief period with Flash, still runs today.
00:28:03.700 | The web page I did in ninth grade would render on a modern browser today, 30 years later.
00:28:10.100 | That is completely crazy.
00:28:12.580 | When you think about the amount of evolution we've had with the web, how much better we've made it, how many more standards browsers have adopted.
00:28:20.700 | It's essentially an Apollo project today to create a new browser, which is why it doesn't happen very often, which is why even companies like Microsoft have to throw in the towel and say, we can't do it.
00:28:30.920 | Now, I actually don't think that's good for the web.
00:28:33.700 | There is the danger of the monoculture if we just get a single browser engine that runs everything, and we are in danger of that.

00:28:47.160 | I would encourage people to look into that.

00:28:56.820 | Truly independent web browser.
00:28:58.840 | We really need that.
00:29:00.860 | But I can hold that thought in my head at the same time I hold the thought in my head that Google's Chrome was pivotal to the web surviving as the premier web development platform.
00:29:14.340 | If it had not been for Google and their entire business, depending on a thriving open web, Apple, Microsoft, I think would have been just as fine to see the web go away, to disappear into being something that's just served native mobile applications and native desktop applications that they could completely control.
00:29:37.960 | So I have all sorts of problems with Google, but it's not Chrome.

00:39:14.440 | But it really wasn't until Ruby that I started thinking of myself as a programmer.
00:39:20.000 | And the way that came about was that the first time I ever got hired as a professional programmer to write code was actually by Jason Fried, my business partner still.
00:39:31.620 | All the way back in 2001, I had been working on these gaming websites in PHP for essentially 18 months at that point.
00:39:39.740 | No one had been paying me to do code in that regard.

00:39:52.700 | I was just offering solicited advice.
00:39:55.320 | Jason had asked a question on the Internet and I had sent him the answer and he was asking in PHP.
00:40:00.800 | And I'd send him the answer to that question and we started talking and then we started working, which, by the way, is a miracle of what the Internet can allow.
00:40:07.340 | How can a kid in Copenhagen who's never met this guy in Chicago connect just over email and start working together?
00:40:15.780 | And by the way, we're still working together now, 24 years later.
00:40:19.980 | That's incredible.
00:40:20.920 | But we started working together and we started working together on some client projects.
00:40:24.760 | Jason would do the design.
00:40:26.340 | 37 Signals would do design.
00:40:27.940 | I would bring the programming PHP.

00:40:38.040 | That whenever you work with a client, you start that project off an email.
00:40:42.680 | Oh, yeah, let's work together.
00:40:44.460 | Here's what we're building.

00:40:54.400 | They don't have the context.

00:40:59.320 | It's like final, final V06 2.0.
00:41:02.880 | That's the one to get.

00:41:04.680 | A beautiful mess in some ways.
00:41:06.500 | A mess that still runs the vast majority of projects to this day.
00:41:10.020 | Email is the lowest common denominator.
00:41:12.020 | That's wonderful.
00:41:13.740 | But we had dropped the ball a couple of times in serious ways with customers.
00:41:18.100 | And we thought we can do better.
00:41:20.040 | We know how to make web applications.
00:41:22.180 | Can't we just make a system that's better than email for managing projects?
00:41:26.800 | It can't be that hard.
00:41:28.060 | We've been doing blogs.
00:41:30.040 | We've been doing to-do lists.
00:41:31.300 | Let's put some of these things together and just make a system where everything that anyone involved in the project needs is on one page.
00:41:39.140 | And it has to be simple enough that I'm not going to run a seminar teaching you how to use the system.
00:41:44.660 | I'm just going to give you the login code.
00:41:46.040 | You're going to jump into it.
00:41:46.960 | So that's Basecamp.
00:41:49.440 | And when we started working on Basecamp, I, for the first time in the experience I had with Jason, had the freedom of technology choice.
00:42:00.220 | There was no client telling me, yeah, PHP, that sounds good.
00:42:04.000 | We know PHP.
00:42:04.700 | Can you build it in PHP?
00:42:05.720 | I had free reigns.
00:42:08.160 | And at that time, I'd been reading IEEE magazine and a couple of other magazines back from the early 2000s where Dave Thomas and Martin Fowler had been writing about programming patterns and how to write better code.
00:42:27.320 | And these two guys, in particular, were both using Ruby to explain their concepts because Ruby looked like pseudocode.
00:42:36.580 | Whether you were programming in C or Java or PHP, all three constituencies could understand Ruby because it basically just reads like English.
00:42:44.160 | So these guys were using Ruby to describe their concepts.
00:42:47.440 | And first of all, I would read these articles for just the concepts they were explaining.
00:42:52.240 | And I'd be like, what is this programming language?
00:42:55.440 | I mean, I like the concept you're explaining, but I also want to see the programming language.
00:42:59.340 | Why haven't I heard of this?
00:43:01.940 | So I started looking into Ruby.
00:43:04.300 | And I realized at that time, Ruby might not be known by anyone, but it's actually been around for a long time.
00:43:10.760 | Matz, the Japanese creator of Ruby, had started working on Ruby back in 93, before the Internet was even a thing.
00:43:19.680 | And here I am in 2003, 10 years later, picking up what seems like this hidden gem that's just laying in obscurity in plain sight.
00:43:31.580 | But Dave Thomas and Martin Fowler, I think, successfully put me and a handful of other people on the trail of a programming language that hadn't been used much in the West, but could be.
00:43:46.900 | So I picked up Ruby and I thought, this is, this is very different.
00:43:51.860 | First of all, where are all the semicolons?
00:43:54.840 | I'd been programming in PHP, in ASP.
00:43:59.020 | I'd even done some Pascal.
00:44:00.260 | I'd looked at some C.
00:44:01.960 | There are semicolons everywhere.
00:44:03.600 | And that was the first thing that struck me is where are the damn semicolons?
00:44:08.160 | And I started thinking, actually, why do we have semicolons in programming?
00:44:12.440 | They're to tell the interpreter that there's a new line of instructions, but I don't need him as a human.
00:44:19.980 | How?
00:44:20.820 | Oh, someone is looking out for the human here, not for the machine.
00:44:25.840 | So that really got me interested.
00:44:28.120 | And then I thought to myself, do you know what?
00:44:31.040 | I know PHP quite well.
00:44:32.220 | I'm not an amazing programmer.
00:44:34.520 | I haven't been working in programming for all that long.
00:44:38.080 | But maybe I can figure it out.
00:44:40.640 | I'm going to give myself two weeks.
00:44:42.400 | I'm going to write a proof of concept where I talk to a database.
00:44:46.440 | I pull some records.
00:44:48.740 | I format them a bit and I display them on an HTML page.
00:44:51.800 | Can I figure that out in a couple of weeks?
00:44:53.360 | It took about one weekend and I was completely mesmerized.
00:44:58.900 | I was completely mind blown because Ruby was made for my brain like a perfect tailored glove by someone I'd never met.
00:45:12.000 | Like, how is this even possible?
00:45:14.300 | We should say maybe, like, paint a picture of the certain qualities that Ruby has, maybe even compared to PHP.
00:45:20.420 | We should also say that there's a ridiculous thing that I'm used to that I forget about, that there's dollar signs everywhere.
00:45:27.760 | Yes.
00:45:28.160 | PHP.
00:45:28.520 | Yes.
00:45:29.080 | There's line noise.
00:45:30.500 | That's what I like to call it.
00:45:31.640 | Line noise.
00:45:32.340 | Line noise.
00:45:33.640 | That's such a beautiful phrase.
00:45:34.900 | Yeah.
00:45:35.620 | So there's all these things that look like programs.
00:45:38.600 | And with Ruby, I mean, there's some similarities in Python there.
00:45:43.100 | It just looks kind of like natural language.
00:45:45.420 | You can read it normally.
00:45:47.180 | Here's a while loop that does five iterations.
00:45:50.140 | You can literally type the number five dot.
00:45:54.340 | Now I'm calling a method under number five, by the way.
00:45:57.260 | That's one of the beautiful aspects of Ruby.
00:45:59.600 | That primitives, like integers, are also objects.
00:46:03.960 | And you can call five dot times start brackets.
00:46:10.040 | Now you're iterating over the code in that bracket five times.
00:46:14.120 | That's it.
00:46:15.060 | Okay.
00:46:15.420 | That's nice.
00:46:16.040 | That's not just nice.
00:46:17.620 | That's exceptional.
00:46:18.340 | There is literally no other programming language that I know of that has managed to boil away the line noise that almost every other programming language would inject into a five-time iteration over a block of code to that extent.
00:46:32.620 | That's a really nice.
00:46:33.680 | Oh, thank you for giving that example.
00:46:35.100 | That's a beautiful example.
00:46:36.720 | Wow.
00:46:38.000 | I don't think I know a programming language that does that.
00:46:40.320 | That's really nice.
00:46:41.020 | Ruby is full of that.
00:46:42.160 | And there's...
00:46:43.660 | So let me dive into a couple of examples.
00:46:44.900 | Because I really think it helps paint the picture.
00:46:46.960 | And let me preface this by saying, I actually, I like the ethos of Python.
00:46:51.600 | I think the Ruby and the Python community share a lot of similarities.
00:46:56.020 | They're both dynamic, interpreted languages.
00:46:58.820 | They're both focused on immediacy and productivity and ease of use in a bunch of ways.
00:47:05.440 | But then they're also very different in many other ways.
00:47:08.060 | And one of the ways they're very different is aesthetically.
00:47:12.160 | Python, to me, I hope I don't offend people too much.
00:47:15.340 | I've said this before.
00:47:16.100 | It's just, it's ugly.
00:47:17.820 | And it's ugly in its base because it's full of superfluous instructions that are necessary for legacy reasons of when Guido made Python back in 87 that are still here in 2025.
00:47:34.620 | And my brain can't cope with that.
00:47:36.820 | Let me give you a basic example.
00:47:38.060 | When you make a class in Python, the initializer method, the starting method, is def.
00:47:44.280 | Okay, fair enough.
00:47:45.080 | That's actually the same as Ruby.
00:47:46.060 | D-E-F, definition of a method.
00:47:48.020 | Then it is underscore.
00:47:50.400 | Not one.
00:47:52.200 | Underscore.
00:47:53.640 | Two.
00:47:54.440 | In it.
00:47:55.900 | Underscore.
00:47:57.520 | Underscore.
00:47:58.140 | Yeah.
00:47:58.660 | Parenthesis start.
00:48:00.320 | Self.
00:48:01.420 | Comma.
00:48:02.460 | And then the first argument.
00:48:03.760 | Yeah, the whole self thing.
00:48:04.680 | Yeah.
00:48:04.940 | I look at that and go, I'm sorry, I'm out.
00:48:08.440 | I can't do it.
00:48:09.160 | It's just, it's everything about it offends my sensibilities to the core.
00:48:14.480 | Here you have the most important method that all new objects or classes have to implement.
00:48:20.800 | And it is one of the most aesthetically offensive ways of typing initialized that I've ever seen anywhere.
00:48:26.660 | And you guys are okay with this?
00:48:28.780 | Yeah, you're making me, you know, you're like talking about my marriage or something like this.
00:48:33.420 | And I'm not realizing I've been in a toxic relationship all along yet.
00:48:37.440 | I just get used to it.
00:48:38.700 | That to me, by the way, was the magic of Ruby.
00:48:41.400 | It opened my eyes to how beautiful programs could be.
00:48:45.860 | I didn't know.
00:48:47.140 | I'd been working in ASP.
00:48:48.780 | I'd been working in PHP.
00:48:49.860 | I didn't even have the concept that aesthetics, beautiful code, was something we could optimize for.
00:48:56.620 | That's something we could pursue.
00:48:58.160 | And even more than that, that we could pursue it above other objectives.
00:49:02.620 | That Ruby is as beautiful as it is.
00:49:06.060 | It's not an accident.
00:49:06.980 | And it's not easy.
00:49:08.160 | Ruby itself is implemented in C.
00:49:10.700 | It's very difficult to parse Ruby code.
00:49:13.820 | Because Ruby is written for humans.
00:49:16.220 | And humans are messy creatures.
00:49:18.420 | They like things in just the right way.
00:49:21.360 | I can't fully explain why the underscore, underscore, init, underscore, underscore make me repulse.
00:49:28.980 | But it does.
00:49:29.980 | And when I look at the Ruby alternative, it's really instructive.
00:49:33.540 | So it's def, same part, def, space, initialize, parentheses.
00:49:40.480 | Not even parentheses.
00:49:41.680 | If you don't need to call it within the arguments, there's not even a parentheses.
00:49:44.200 | That in itself is actually also a major part.
00:49:46.160 | If the human doesn't need the additional characters, we're not just going to put them in because it'd be nicer to parse for the computer.
00:49:53.440 | We're going to get rid of the semicolons.
00:49:55.500 | We're going to get rid of the parentheses.
00:49:57.220 | We're going to get rid of the underscores.
00:50:00.240 | We're going to get rid of all that ugliness, all the line noise, and boil it down to its pure essentials.
00:50:05.500 | And at the same time, we're not going to abbreviate.
00:50:09.120 | This is a key difference in the aesthetics between Ruby and Python as well.
00:50:13.820 | Init is short of the type.
00:50:16.120 | It's only five characters.
00:50:17.140 | Initialize is a lot longer, but it looks a lot better.
00:50:20.440 | And you don't type it very often.
00:50:22.680 | So you should look at something pretty.
00:50:24.500 | If you don't have to do it all the time, it's okay that it's long.
00:50:28.020 | Those kinds of aesthetic evaluations are rife all over the Ruby language.
00:50:34.320 | But let me give you an even better example.
00:50:36.940 | If conditional, that's the bedrug of all programming languages.
00:50:41.740 | They have the if conditional.
00:50:43.320 | If you take most programming languages, they all have if.
00:50:46.560 | That's basically the same in almost every language.
00:50:48.640 | Space.
00:50:49.540 | Start parentheses.
00:50:50.840 | We all do that.
00:50:52.560 | And then you have perhaps, let's say you're calling an object called user dot is admin, close parentheses, close parentheses, start brackets, and here's what we're going to do if the user's an admin, right?
00:51:11.260 | That would be a normal programming language.
00:51:12.780 | Ruby doesn't do it like that.
00:51:14.540 | Ruby boils almost all of it away.
00:51:16.800 | We start with the if.
00:51:17.500 | Okay, that's the same.
00:51:18.380 | No parentheses necessary because there's no ambiguity for the human to distinguish that the next part is just a single statement.
00:51:27.760 | So you do if space user dot admin question mark.
00:51:35.320 | Yeah.
00:51:38.260 | No open brackets, no parentheses, no nothing.
00:51:42.220 | Next open line, here's your conditional.
00:51:45.140 | That question mark means nothing to the computer, but it means something to the human.
00:51:52.780 | Ruby put in the predicate method style purely as a communication tool between humans.
00:52:02.400 | It's actually more work for the interpreter to be able to see that this question mark is there.
00:52:08.160 | Why is this question mark in here?
00:52:09.560 | Because it just reads so nicely.
00:52:12.460 | If user admin question mark.
00:52:15.260 | That's a very human phrase, but it gets better.
00:52:19.080 | You can turn this around.
00:52:21.560 | You can have your statement you want to execute before the conditional.
00:52:26.920 | You can do user dot upgrade, say you're calling an upgrade method on a user, space if space user dot admin question mark.
00:52:37.780 | We do the thing if the thing is true.
00:52:41.060 | Instead of saying if the thing is true, do the thing.
00:52:43.780 | But it gets even better.
00:52:45.100 | This is why I love this example with the conditional because you can keep diving into it.
00:52:48.700 | So let's flip it around.
00:52:50.980 | User dot downgrade if exclamation point not user dot admin, right?
00:52:59.680 | That'd be a typical way of writing it.
00:53:01.360 | Ruby goes, that exclamation point is light and noise.
00:53:05.440 | Why do we have if and then an exclamation point?
00:53:08.400 | That's ugly.
00:53:08.940 | We could do user dot downgrade unless user admin question mark.
00:53:16.720 | That to me is an encapsulation of the incredible beauty that Ruby affords the programmer through ambiguity that is only to serve the human reader and writer.
00:53:30.940 | All of these statements we've just discussed, they're the same for the computer.
00:53:34.420 | It'll compile down to the same C code.
00:53:36.960 | They'll compile down to the same assembly code.
00:53:39.260 | It makes no difference whatsoever.
00:53:40.860 | In fact, it just makes it harder to write an interpreter.
00:53:43.760 | But for the human who gets to choose whether the statement comes before the conditional or the predicate method has, it's just incredible.
00:53:52.300 | It reads like poetry at some point.
00:53:54.920 | It's also incredible that, you know, one language designer is creating that.
00:53:59.700 | You know, Guido van Rossum also.
00:54:01.780 | It's like one person gets to make these extremely difficult decisions because it's, you have to think about how does that all get parsed.
00:54:09.780 | And you have to think about the thousands, if it's a popular language, of millions of people that end up using this.
00:54:17.340 | And what they feel with that question mark on the, for the if statement, what does that feel like?
00:54:23.720 | That's what Matt's thought about because he started his entire mission off a different premise.
00:54:28.820 | Then almost every programming language designer that I'd heard at least articulate their vision, that his number one goal was programmer happiness.
00:54:37.580 | That his number one goal was the affordances that would allow programmers to articulate code in ways that not just executed correctly, but were a joy to write and were a joy to read.
00:54:53.840 | And that vision is based on a fundamentally different view of humanity.
00:55:00.300 | There's no greater contrast between Matt's and James Gosselin, the designer of Java.
00:55:06.380 | I wanted to listen to James talk about the design of Java.
00:55:11.060 | Why was it the way it was?
00:55:12.780 | Why was it so rigid?
00:55:14.180 | And he was very blunt about it, which, by the way, I really appreciate.
00:55:17.540 | And I think Gosselin has done a tremendous job with Java.
00:55:20.540 | But his view of humanity is rather dark.
00:55:23.520 | His view of humanity was programmers, at the average, are stupid creatures.
00:55:29.760 | They cannot be trusted with sophisticated programming languages because they're going to shoot their foot off or their hand off.
00:55:39.940 | And that would be kind of inconvenient to the regional development office of a mid-tier insurance company writing code that has to last for 20 years.
00:55:52.380 | Now, it's actually a very Thomas Sowell view of constrained capacity in humans that I've come to appreciate much later in life.
00:56:01.080 | But it's also a very depressing view of programmers that there are just certain programmers who are too dumb to appreciate code poetry.
00:56:10.860 | They're too ignorant to learn how to write it well.
00:56:13.980 | We need to give them a sandbox where they just won't hurt themselves too much.
00:56:19.160 | Matz went the complete opposite direction.
00:56:23.160 | He believes in humanity.
00:56:25.120 | He believes in the unlimited capacity of programmers to learn and become better.
00:56:30.660 | So much so that he's willing to put the stranger at his own level.
00:56:37.920 | This is the second part I truly appreciate about Ruby.
00:56:42.100 | Ruby allows you to extend base classes.
00:56:46.060 | You know how we just talked about five dot times is a way to iterate over a statement five times?
00:56:53.040 | That five is obviously a base class.
00:56:55.360 | It's a number.
00:56:56.800 | Do you know what?
00:56:57.840 | You can add your own methods to that.
00:57:00.260 | I did extensively.
00:57:03.160 | In Rails, we have something called active support, which is essentially my dialect of Ruby for programming web applications.
00:57:11.440 | And I'll give you one example.
00:57:12.620 | I've added a method called days to the number.
00:57:17.320 | So if you do five dot days, you get five days in seconds because seconds is the way we set cash expiration times and other things like that.
00:57:27.540 | So you can say cash expires in five dot days and you're going to get whatever five times 24 times 60 times 60 is or whatever the math is.
00:57:41.160 | Right.
00:57:41.580 | In a normal programming language, you would type out the seconds and then you would have a little comment above it saying this represent five days.
00:57:50.880 | In Ruby, you get to write five days.
00:57:53.220 | But even better than that, Matt's didn't come up with it.
00:57:56.000 | Matt's didn't need the five days.
00:57:58.560 | I needed that because I needed to expire cashes.
00:58:01.240 | I was allowed by Matt's to extend his story with my own chapters on equal footing such that a reader of Ruby could not tell the difference between the code Matt's wrote and the code that I wrote.
00:58:16.180 | He trusted me as a complete stranger from Denmark who had never met to mess with his beautiful story.
00:58:24.280 | That level of trust is essentially unheard of.
00:58:27.820 | I know there are other program languages that allow things with macros and so forth, but none do it in a way like Ruby does it.
00:58:34.380 | None does it with an articulated vision of humanity, a trust in humanity like Matt's does.
00:58:41.220 | That is the opposite end of the spectrum of Java.
00:58:46.080 | Yeah, I mean for my aesthetic sensibilities, just the way you described five dot days, that's really pleasant to me.
00:58:53.680 | I could see myself sitting alone, sleep deprived, and just writing that.
00:59:00.400 | It's just an easy thing.
00:59:02.060 | You can write it in a long way with a comment.
00:59:04.020 | You can write it in multiple lines.
00:59:05.640 | Now with AI, I'm sure it's going to generate it correctly, but there's something really pleasant about the simplicity of that.
00:59:11.700 | I'm not sure what that is, but you're right.
00:59:13.860 | There is a good feeling there, and I'm sure we'll talk about happiness from all kinds of philosophical angles, but that is what happiness is made of.
00:59:25.800 | That little good feeling there.
00:59:28.300 | It's the good feeling that come out of a concept compressed to its pure essence.
00:59:35.040 | There's nothing you can take away from that statement that's superfluous.
00:59:39.040 | But see, I also want to push back a little bit, because it's not, because I also programmed in Perl a bunch, just to be cool.
00:59:47.880 | So like, it's not all about compression.
00:59:51.020 | No, you can compress it too far.
00:59:53.020 | Perl Golf is a thing where you can turn programs into something that's unreadable for humans.
00:59:59.580 | Now, the great thing about Perl was that it came out before Ruby.
01:00:02.660 | Matz was a great student of Wall, was a great student of Perl, was a great student of Python and Smalltalk and Lisp.
01:00:12.720 | He took inspiration from all of these prior attempts at creating good programming languages and really edited down the very best bits into this.
01:00:22.180 | So he was able to learn from his lessons.
01:00:24.320 | But what I found incredible about Ruby is that here we are, 2025, Ruby has been worked on for over 30 years.
01:00:32.380 | And essentially, the first draft is 90% of what we're still using.
01:00:38.060 | There was almost a sense of divine inspiration possible in wherever Matz was writing that initial version of Ruby that transcended time to such a degree that no one has still even begun to reach it.
01:00:51.520 | And this is the other thing I always find fascinating.
01:00:53.160 | I generally believe in the efficient market theory, that if someone comes up with a better mousetrap or better idea, others will eventually copy them to such an extent that perhaps the original mousetrap is no longer even remembered.
01:01:06.560 | No one has been able to copy that essence of Ruby.
01:01:09.960 | They borrowed elements, and that's totally fine.
01:01:12.540 | But Ruby still stands taller than everyone else on these metrics, on this trust in humanity and programmers.
01:01:20.860 | And we should also say, like, you know, maybe the perfect programming language is that metric.
01:01:26.920 | And then there's the successful language, and those are often different.
01:01:30.380 | There is something wonderful about the Brendan Eich story of creating JavaScript.
01:01:33.980 | Yes.
01:01:35.140 | There's something truly beautiful about the way JavaScript took over the world.
01:01:43.300 | I've recently got to visit the Amazon jungle, and just one of my favorite things to do is just to watch the ants take over anything, everything.
01:01:49.920 | And it's just like, it's a nice distributed system.
01:01:53.140 | It's a messy thing that doesn't seem to be order, but it just works.
01:01:56.980 | And the machinery of it.
01:01:58.520 | Worse is better.
01:01:59.440 | I mean, that's actually the name of a pattern in software development and other ways of how is the pattern of Linux.
01:02:06.720 | Linux was quantifiably worse than, I think it was Minix at the time.
01:02:11.600 | Other ways of it that were more cathedral, less bizarre, and it's still one.
01:02:19.080 | That there's something to it that the imperfections can help something go forward.
01:02:23.620 | It's actually a trick I've studied to the degree that I now incorporate it in almost all open source that I do.
01:02:29.880 | I make sure that when I release the first version of any new thing I work on, it's a little broken.
01:02:35.320 | It's a little busted in ways that invite people to come in and help me.
01:02:40.220 | Because there's no easier way to get the collaboration of other programmers than to put something out that they know how to fix and improve.
01:02:48.960 | Yeah, that's awesome.
01:02:49.780 | But Ruby is somehow, or was at least, a little bit different in that regard.
01:02:54.020 | Not in all regards.
01:02:55.160 | Matt's got the ethos of the language, the design of the language just right.
01:03:00.020 | But the first versions of Ruby were terribly slow.
01:03:03.140 | It's taken, I mean, hundreds of man years to get Ruby to be both this beautiful, yet also highly efficient and really fast.
01:03:14.860 | And we should say that the thing that made you fall in love with this particular programming,
01:03:18.840 | language is metaprogramming.
01:03:20.400 | Yes.
01:03:21.380 | So that takes all of these elements we've just talked about and turned them up to 11.
01:03:26.540 | I'll explain metaprogramming real simple.
01:03:28.640 | Metaprogramming is essentially a version of the five-dot days.
01:03:33.920 | You get to add keywords to the language.
01:03:37.240 | Active record is the part of Rails that communicates with the database.
01:03:42.660 | This is a system where every table in the database is represented by a class.
01:03:49.620 | So if we take the user example again, you do class user descends from active record base.
01:03:57.080 | And then the first line you can write is this.
01:04:00.000 | I want my users to have many posts or have many comments.
01:04:04.140 | Let's do that.
01:04:04.900 | We're making some system where users can make comments.
01:04:06.800 | The very next line is has underscore many space colon comments.
01:04:14.760 | Now you've set up a dependency between users and comments that will give you a whole host of access and factory methods for users to be able to own comments, to create comments, to update comments.
01:04:27.760 | In that line alone, has many looks like a keyword.
01:04:32.740 | It looks like it's part of the Ruby language.
01:04:34.900 | That's metaprogramming.
01:04:36.080 | When Rails is able to add these elements to how you define a class, and then that runs code that adds a bunch of methods to the user class, that's metaprogramming.
01:04:48.220 | And when metaprogramming is used in this way, we call it domain-specific languages.
01:04:53.400 | You take a generic language like Ruby, and you tailor it to a certain domain like describing relationships in a database at a object level.
01:05:04.400 | And this is one of those early examples where you can do user has many comments, belongs underscore to space colon account.
01:05:15.440 | Now you've set up a one-to-one relationship before we had a one-to-many relationship.
01:05:21.180 | Rails is rife with all these kinds of domain-specific languages where sometimes it doesn't even look like Ruby.
01:05:28.880 | You can't identify Ruby keywords.
01:05:31.460 | You can just identify what looks like keywords in its own programming language.
01:05:37.360 | Now, again, I know that Lisp and others also do this stuff.
01:05:41.720 | They just do it with the maximum amount of line noise that can ever be crammed into a programming language.
01:05:48.660 | And Ruby does it at a level where you cannot tell my metaprogramming from Matt's keywords and with zero line noise.
01:05:55.980 | Yeah, I should say that my first love was Lisp.
01:05:58.380 | So there's a slow tear that you can't see.
01:06:01.400 | I've actually never written any real Lisp myself.
01:06:04.580 | Well, how can you judge it so harshly then?
01:06:06.640 | Because I have two eyes and I can look at code and my aesthetic sensibilities forbid me to even go much further, which is a limitation.
01:06:14.440 | I know I should actually dive into Lisp because I found that I've learned a lot just diving into, maybe I'm insulting Lisp again here, but the past of programming languages.
01:06:24.820 | With Smalltalk, for example, I think Smalltalk is a incredible experiment that also worked, but isn't suitable for today's programming environments.
01:06:35.860 | I love that we're talking about Ruby so much and what beautiful code is, what a beautiful programming language is.
01:06:41.540 | So one of the things that is, I think, implied, maybe you made explicit in your descriptions there is that Ruby is dynamic typing versus strict typing.
01:06:52.040 | And you have been not just saying that it's a nice thing, but that you will defend dynamic typing to the death.
01:07:00.180 | Like that freedom is a powerful freedom to preserve.
01:07:04.060 | It's the essence of what makes Ruby, Ruby.
01:07:07.220 | This is why I don't fully understand when people call for Ruby to add static typing, because to me, it's the bedrock of what this is.
01:07:15.420 | Why would you want to turn one of the most beautiful languages into something far uglier?
01:07:21.480 | This is one of my primary objections to static typing.
01:07:25.460 | It's not just that it limits you in certain ways.
01:07:28.480 | It makes metaprogramming harder.
01:07:30.100 | I write a bunch of metaprogramming.
01:07:32.220 | I've seen what it takes to do metaprogramming in TypeScript.
01:07:34.880 | That was actually one of the things that just really sent me on a tear of getting meta or getting TypeScript out of some of the projects that I'm involved with.
01:07:42.000 | We pulled TypeScript out of Turbo, one of the front-end frameworks that we have, because I tried to write to metaprogramming in TypeScript, and I was just infuriated.
01:07:52.740 | I don't want that experience.
01:07:54.540 | But I also don't want it from an aesthetic point of view.
01:07:57.660 | I hate repetition.
01:07:58.980 | We've just talked about how much I love that Ruby boils all of these expressions down to its essence.
01:08:06.020 | You can't remove one dot.
01:08:07.980 | You can't remove one character without losing something.
01:08:11.220 | This moment you go for static typing that you declare, at least.
01:08:14.560 | I know there are ways to do implied typing and so forth.
01:08:17.460 | But let's just take the stereotypical case of the Java example, for example.
01:08:21.520 | Capital U, user.
01:08:24.720 | I'm declaring the type of the variable.
01:08:27.320 | Lowercase user.
01:08:29.100 | I'm now naming my variable.
01:08:31.340 | Equals uppercase user or new uppercase user.
01:08:35.020 | I've repeated user three times.
01:08:37.040 | I don't have time for this.
01:08:40.260 | I don't have sensibilities for this.
01:08:42.560 | I don't want my Ruby polluted with this.
01:08:45.600 | Now, I understand all the arguments for why people like static typing.
01:08:49.700 | One of the primary arguments is that it makes tooling easier.
01:08:53.180 | It makes it easier to do autocomplete in editors, for example.
01:08:56.560 | It makes it easier to find certain kinds of bugs, because maybe you're calling methods that don't exist on an object,
01:09:04.740 | and the editor can actually catch that bug before you even run it.
01:09:09.440 | I don't care.
01:09:10.420 | First of all, I don't write code with tools.
01:09:14.720 | I write them with text editors.
01:09:16.860 | I chisel them out of the screen with my bare hands.
01:09:21.620 | I don't autocomplete.
01:09:22.980 | And this is why I love Ruby so much, and this is why I continue to be in love with the text editor rather than the IDE.
01:09:30.420 | I don't want an IDE.
01:09:32.360 | I want my fingers to have to individually type out every element of it,
01:09:38.400 | because it will force me to stay in the world where Ruby is beautiful.
01:09:43.420 | Because as soon as it gets easy to type a lot of boilerplate, well, guess what?
01:09:47.900 | You're going to have a lot of boilerplate.
01:09:48.920 | Every single language, basically, that has great tooling support has a much higher tolerance for boilerplate,
01:09:56.760 | because the thinking is, well, you're not typing it anyway.
01:09:59.220 | You're just autocompleting it.
01:10:00.680 | I don't want that at all.
01:10:01.880 | I want something where the fabric I'm working in is just a text file.
01:10:08.240 | There's nothing else to it.
01:10:10.120 | So, these things play together.
01:10:12.020 | There's the aesthetic part.
01:10:13.240 | There's the tooling part.
01:10:14.580 | There's the metaprogramming part.
01:10:16.460 | There's the fact that Ruby's ethos of duck typing, I don't know if you've heard that term before.
01:10:23.020 | It's essentially not about, can I call this method if an object is of a certain class?
01:10:30.260 | It is, can I call this method if the method responds?
01:10:34.460 | It's very out of small talk in that regard.
01:10:36.680 | You don't actually check of whether that class has the method, which allows you to dynamically add methods at runtime
01:10:44.980 | and do all sorts of really interesting things that underpin all the beautiful metaprogramming that we do in Ruby.
01:10:50.620 | I don't want to lose any of that.
01:10:52.460 | And I don't care for the benefits.
01:10:54.960 | One of the benefits I've seen touted over and over again is that it's much easier to write correct software.
01:11:00.920 | You're going to have fewer bugs.
01:11:02.400 | You're going to have less null pointer exceptions.
01:11:05.800 | You're going to have less, all of this stuff.
01:11:07.280 | Yeah, I don't have any of that.
01:11:08.620 | It's just not something that occurs in my standard mode of operation.
01:11:12.960 | I'm not saying I don't have bugs.
01:11:14.480 | Of course I do.
01:11:15.120 | But I catch those bugs with unit testing, with integration testing.
01:11:19.220 | Those are the kinds of precautions that will catch logical bugs, things that compile but are wrong,
01:11:27.440 | along with the uncompilable stuff.
01:11:30.520 | So I've never been drawn into this world.
01:11:33.640 | And part of it is because I work on a certain class of systems.
01:11:36.260 | I fully accept that.
01:11:37.500 | If you're writing systems that have 5, 10, 50 million lines of code with hundreds, thousands,
01:11:44.600 | or tens of thousands of programmers, I fully accept that you need different methods.
01:11:49.740 | What I object to is the idea that what's right for a code base of 10 million lines of code with 100,000 programmers working on it
01:11:57.280 | is also the same thing I should be using in my bedroom to create Basecamp because I'm just a single individual.
01:12:03.240 | That's complete nonsense.
01:12:04.960 | In the real world, we would know that that makes no sense at all.
01:12:08.420 | That you don't, I don't know, use your Pagani to go pick up groceries at Costco.
01:12:13.700 | It's a bad vehicle for that.
01:12:16.260 | It just doesn't have the space.
01:12:17.560 | You don't want to muddy the beautiful seats.
01:12:19.640 | You don't want to do any of those things.
01:12:20.640 | We know that certain things that are very good in certain domains don't apply to all.
01:12:26.200 | In programming languages, it seems like we forget that.
01:12:28.680 | Now, to be fair, I also had a little bit, perhaps, of a reputation of forgetting that.
01:12:32.800 | When I first learned Ruby, I was so head over heels in love with this programming language
01:12:37.780 | that I almost found it unconceivable that anyone would choose any other programming language at all to write web applications.
01:12:44.840 | And I kind of engaged the evangelism of Ruby on Rails in that spirit as a crusade,
01:12:51.300 | as I just need to teach you the gospel.
01:12:54.000 | I just need to show you this conditional code that we just talked about.
01:12:57.320 | And you will convert at the point of a sharp argument.
01:13:01.420 | Now, I learned that that's not the way.
01:13:03.220 | And part of the reason it's not the way is that programmers think differently.
01:13:06.480 | Our brains are configured differently.
01:13:09.780 | My brain is configured perfectly for Ruby, perfectly for a dynamically duct-typed language
01:13:18.080 | that I can chisel code out of a text editor with.
01:13:22.100 | And other people need the security of an IDE.
01:13:26.460 | They want the security of classes that won't compile unless you call the methods on it.
01:13:33.120 | I have come to accept that.
01:13:34.980 | But most programmers don't.
01:13:36.400 | They're still stuck in, essentially, I like static typing.
01:13:40.380 | Therefore, static typing is the only way to create reliable, correct systems.
01:13:45.260 | Which is just such a mind-blowing, to be blunt, idiotic thing to say in the face of evidence,
01:13:52.340 | mountains of evidence to the contrary.
01:13:54.740 | This is one of the reasons I'm so in love with Shopify as the flagship application for Ruby on Rails.
01:14:03.860 | Shopify exists at a scale that most programmers will never touch.
01:14:09.580 | On Black Friday, I think Shopify did 1 million requests per second.
01:14:14.880 | That's not 1 million requests of images.
01:14:17.860 | That's of dynamic requests that are funneling through the pipeline of commerce.
01:14:22.740 | I mean, Shopify runs something like 30% of all e-commerce stores on the damn internet.
01:14:28.600 | A huge portion of all commerce in total runs through Shopify, and that runs on Ruby on Rails.
01:14:35.460 | So, Ruby on Rails is able to scale up to that level without using static typing in all of what it does.
01:14:45.500 | Now, I know they've done certain experiments in certain ways, because they are hitting some of the limits that you will hit with dynamic typing.
01:14:51.100 | And some of those limits you hit with dynamic typing are actually, by the way, just limits you hit when you write 5 million lines of code.
01:14:58.180 | I think the Shopify monolith is about 5 million lines of code.
01:15:01.440 | At that scale, everything breaks, because you're at the frontier of what humans are capable of doing with programming languages.
01:15:09.460 | The difference, in part, is that Ruby is such a succinct language, that those 5 million, if they'd been written in, let's just say, Go or Java, would have been 50 or 25.
01:15:19.680 | Now, that might have alleviated some of the problems that you have when you work on huge systems with many programmers,
01:15:27.100 | but it certainly would also have compounded them, trying to understand 25 million lines of code.
01:15:32.640 | So, the thing does scale.
01:15:34.200 | That's a persistent myth, that it doesn't scale.
01:15:36.940 | Shopify and others, but Shopify, I think, is a great example.
01:15:41.500 | By the way, I love Shopify, and I love Toby.
01:15:44.920 | You've got to have Toby on.
01:15:46.260 | Yeah, for sure.
01:15:47.000 | Let's talk to you about this morning.
01:15:47.480 | For sure.
01:15:47.960 | He's a brilliant...
01:15:48.860 | I got to hang out with him in the desert somewhere, I forget, in Utah.

01:17:01.500 | A level of criticality I can't even begin to understand.
01:17:05.300 | And yet we can see eye to eye on so many of these fundamental questions in computer science and program development.
01:17:12.860 | That is a dynamic range to be able to encompass Rails being a great tool for the one developer who's just starting out with an idea, who don't even fully know everything, who is right at the level where PHP would have been a good fit in those late 90s because, yeah, I could probably upload something to an FTP server and so on.
01:17:32.720 | Rails does have more complexity than that, but it also has so much longer runway.
01:17:37.540 | The runway goes all the way to goddamn Shopify.
01:17:39.780 | That is about the most convincing argument I can make for sort of dynamic range that we can do a lot of it.
01:17:46.200 | And even having said that, Shopify is the outlier, of course.
01:17:50.480 | I don't think about Shopify as the primary target when I write Rails.
01:17:55.680 | I think of the single developer.
01:17:57.320 | Actually, I do think about Shopify, but I don't think about Shopify now.
01:18:00.960 | I think of Shopify when Toby was writing Snow Devil, which was the first e-commerce store to sell snowboards that he created that was the pre-Shopify Shopify.
01:18:10.140 | He created it all by himself.
01:18:12.020 | And that was possible because Ruby on Rails isn't just about beautiful code.
01:18:17.440 | It's just as much about productivity.
01:18:19.560 | It's just as much about the impact that an individual programmer is able to have, that they can build a system where they can keep the whole thing in their head and be able to move it forward such that you can go from one developer sitting and working on something, and that something is Shopify, and it turns into what it is today.
01:18:37.680 | When we talk about programming languages and we compare them, we often compare them at a very late stage.
01:18:42.980 | Like, what is the better programming language for, let's say, Twitter in 2009, when it's already a huge success?
01:18:49.260 | Twitter was started on Ruby on Rails.
01:18:51.180 | They then hit some scaling problems.
01:18:53.160 | It was a big debacle at the time.
01:18:55.240 | They end up then, I think, writing it in some other language, which, by the way, I think is the best advertisement ever for Ruby on Rails,
01:19:03.720 | because nothing fucking happened for 10 years after they switched over, right?
01:19:07.900 | Essentially, zero innovation.
01:19:09.780 | Some of that was because they were doing a long conversion, and all of the early success, in part, came because they had the agility to quickly change and adopt and so forth.
01:19:20.200 | That's what startups need.
01:19:21.860 | That's what Shopify needed.
01:19:23.120 | That's what Twitter needed.
01:19:24.440 | That's what everyone needs.
01:19:25.580 | And that's the number one priority for Ruby on Rails, to make sure that we don't lose that.
01:19:30.340 | Because what happens so often when development tools and programming language are driven by huge companies is that they mirror their org chart.
01:19:38.700 | React and everything else needed to use that is, in some ways, a reflection of how Meta builds Facebook.
01:19:47.580 | Because, of course, it is.
01:19:48.900 | Because, of course, it's an instruction of that.
01:19:50.620 | I'm not saying React isn't a great tool and that can't be used by smaller teams.
01:19:54.040 | Of course it can.
01:19:54.680 | But it's born in a very different context than something like Ruby on Rails.
01:19:58.960 | Let me say as a small aside, because I think we might return to Shopify and celebrate it often.

01:20:40.440 | But, yeah, I just want to make that explicit.
01:20:42.640 | But to linger on the scaling thing with the Twitter and the Shopify, can you just explain to me what Shopify is doing with the JIT?
01:20:52.140 | What did they have to try to do to scale this thing?
01:20:56.720 | Because that's kind of an incredible story, right?
01:20:58.780 | Yeah.
01:20:59.780 | So one of the great contributions that Shopify has made to the entire Ruby ecosystem, not just Rails, but in particular Rails, is YJIT.
01:21:07.820 | So YJIT is their compiler for Ruby that just makes everything a lot more efficient.
01:21:13.080 | And at Shopify scale, eking out even a 5%, 10% improvement in Ruby's overhead and execution time is a huge deal.
01:21:23.120 | Now, Shopify didn't need YJIT.
01:21:26.400 | Shopify was already running on the initial version of Ruby that was, I think, 10 times slower than what we have today.
01:21:34.680 | If you look back upon the Ruby 1.8.6 that Topi probably started on, just as I started on.
01:21:41.340 | And that was enough to propel Shopify to the scale that it has today.
01:21:45.260 | A lot of the scaling conversation is lost in a failure to distinguish two things.
01:21:52.600 | Scale is kind of one package we talk about when there are really multiple packages inside of it.
01:21:59.600 | One is runtime performance, latency.
01:22:02.720 | How fast can you execute a single request?
01:22:05.420 | Can it happen fast enough that the user will not notice?
01:22:08.740 | If your Rails request takes a second and a half to execute, the user's going to notice.
01:22:13.600 | Your app is going to feel slow and sluggish.
01:22:16.140 | You have to get that response time down below, let's say, at least 300 milliseconds.
01:22:22.040 | I like to target 100 milliseconds as my latency.
01:22:25.020 | That's kind of performance.
01:22:26.580 | How much performance of that kind of latency can you squeeze out of a single CPU core?
01:22:32.280 | That tells you something about what the price of a single request will be.
01:22:36.160 | But then whether you can deal with 1 million requests a second, like Shopify is doing right now.
01:22:43.140 | If you have one box that can do 1,000 requests a second, you just need X boxes to get up to a million.
01:22:50.000 | And what you'll actually find is that when it comes to programming languages, they're all the same in this way.
01:22:55.620 | They all scale largely, beautifully horizontally.
01:22:59.360 | You just add more boxes.
01:23:01.820 | The hard parts of scaling a Shopify is typically not the program language.
01:23:06.820 | It's the database.
01:23:07.940 | And that's actually one of the challenges that Shopify has now is how do you deal with MySQL at the scale that they're operating at?
01:23:18.240 | When do you need to move to other databases to get worldwide performance?
01:23:23.660 | All of these things.
01:23:24.560 | The questions about scaling rupee are economic questions.
01:23:28.380 | If we're spending so and so much on application servers, if we can get just 5% more performance out of Ruby, well, we could save 5% of those servers and that could filter down into the budget.
01:23:38.720 | Now, that analysis concludes into basically one thing.
01:23:43.000 | Ruby is a luxury language.
01:23:46.560 | It's a luxury, the highest luxury, in my opinion.
01:23:51.540 | It is the Kogo Chanel of programming languages, something that not everyone can afford, and I mean this in the best possible way.
01:23:58.780 | There are some applications on the internet where each request has so little value, you can't afford to use a luxurious language like Ruby to program it.
01:24:09.400 | You simply have to slum it with a C or a Go or some other low-level language or a Rust.
01:24:15.700 | Talk about line noise there for a hot second.
01:24:17.660 | The thrift store of languages.
01:24:19.340 | Exactly.
01:24:20.040 | Where you need kind of just, you need a very low level to do it.
01:24:24.240 | You can't afford to use a luxury language to build it with.
01:24:28.240 | That's not true of Shopify.
01:24:30.160 | It wasn't true of Basecamp.
01:24:31.900 | Even back in 2004, it's not been true of 99% of all web applications ever created.
01:24:38.120 | Because the main cost component of 99% of web applications is not CPU cores.
01:24:44.020 | It's wet cores.
01:24:45.980 | It's human cores.
01:24:47.500 | It's human capacity to understand and involve systems.
01:24:51.660 | It's their personal productivity.
01:24:53.560 | I did a calculation once when someone had for the 400th time said that, oh, if you switch from Ruby to some faster language, you could save a bunch of money.
01:25:03.140 | And I calculated it out that at the time, and I think the last time I did this calculation was almost a decade ago, we were spending about 15% of our operating budget on Ruby application servers.
01:25:16.040 | So for me to improve my cost profile of the business by seven percentage points, I'd have to pick something twice as fast.
01:25:26.460 | That's quite hard.
01:25:27.460 | Versus if Ruby and Ruby on Rails was even 10% more productive than something else, I would move the needle far more.
01:25:34.720 | Because making individual programmers more productive actually matters a lot more.
01:25:38.740 | This is why people are so excited about AI.
01:25:40.880 | This is why they're freaking out over the fact that a single programmer in Silicon Valley who makes $300,000 a year can now do the work of three or five, at least in theory.
01:25:52.080 | I haven't actually seen that fully in practice, but let's just assume the theory is correct.
01:25:55.280 | If not now, then in six months.
01:25:57.980 | That's a huge deal.
01:26:00.200 | That matters so much more than whether you can squeeze a few more cycles out of the CPU.
01:26:05.980 | When it comes to these kinds of business applications, if you're making Unreal Engine rendering stuff like Tim Sweeney you had on, yeah, he needs to really sweat all those details.
01:26:16.540 | The Nanite engine can't run on Ruby.
01:26:18.860 | It's never going to.
01:26:20.320 | It was not meant for that.
01:26:21.360 | Fine.
01:26:22.000 | These kinds of business applications absolutely can.
01:26:25.120 | And everything that people are excited about AI for right now, that extra capacity to just do more, that was why we were excited about Ruby back in the early 2000s.
01:26:36.620 | That was because I saw that if we could even squeeze out a 10% improvement of the human programmer, we'd be able to do so much more for so much less.
01:26:47.360 | Probably argue about this, but I really like working together with AI, collaborating with AI.
01:26:55.080 | And I would argue that the kind of code you want AI to generate is human readable, human interpretable.
01:27:00.180 | Yes.
01:27:00.860 | If it's generating Pearl golf code, it's just, it's not a collaboration.
01:27:06.500 | So it has to be speaking the human.
01:27:08.880 | It's not just you're writing the prompts in English.
01:27:11.400 | You also want to read the responses in the human interpretable language like Ruby, right?
01:27:17.280 | So it's, that's actually is beneficial for AI too, because you kind of said that for you, the sculptor, the sort of the elitist Coco Chanel sculptor, you want to, on your fancy keyboard to type every single letter yourself or your own fingers.
01:27:32.340 | But it's also, uh, that, uh, the benefit of Ruby also applies in once that is written by AI and you're actually doing with your own fingers, the editing.
01:27:42.600 | Yes.
01:27:43.640 | Because you can interact with it because it's human interpretable.
01:27:46.640 | The paradigm I really love with this was something Elon actually said on one of your shows when you guys were talking about neural link, that neural link allows the bandwidth.
01:27:56.280 | between you and the machine to increase that language, either spoken or written is very low bandwidth.
01:28:03.140 | If you are to calculate just how many bits we can exchange as we're sitting here, it's very slow.
01:28:09.660 | Ruby.
01:28:11.420 | Has a much higher bandwidth of communication revealed conveys so much more concept per character than most other programming languages do.
01:28:24.400 | So when you are collaborating with AI, you want really high bandwidth.
01:28:28.900 | You want it to be able to produce programs with you, whether you're letting it write the code or not, that both of you can actually understand really quickly.
01:28:39.760 | And that you can compress a grand comp or a grand concept, a grand system into far fewer parts that both of you can understand.
01:28:49.400 | Now, I actually love collaborating with AI too.
01:28:52.220 | I love chiseling my code and the way I use AI is in a separate window.
01:28:57.100 | I don't let it drive my code.
01:28:58.720 | I've tried that.
01:28:59.420 | I've tried the cursors and the wind serves and I don't enjoy that way of writing.
01:29:03.560 | And one of the reasons I don't enjoy that way of writing is I can literally feel competence draining out of my fingers.
01:29:12.060 | And that level of immediacy with the material disappears.
01:29:17.160 | And where I felt this the most was I did this remix of Ubuntu called Omocube when I switched to Linux.
01:29:25.100 | And it's all written in Bash.
01:29:26.900 | I'd never written any serious amount of code in Bash before.
01:29:30.840 | So I was using AI to collaborate to write a bunch of Bash with me because I needed all this.
01:29:35.880 | I knew what I wanted.
01:29:36.820 | I could express it in Ruby.
01:29:38.420 | But I thought it was an interesting challenge to filter through Bash because what I was doing was setting up a Linux machine.
01:29:45.360 | That's basically what Bash was designed for.
01:29:47.560 | It's a great constraint.
01:29:49.080 | But what I found myself doing was asking AI for the same way of expressing a conditional, for example, in Bash over and over again.
01:29:57.380 | That by not typing it, I wasn't learning it.
01:30:01.080 | I was using it.
01:30:02.520 | I was getting the expression I wanted, but I wasn't learning it.
01:30:06.540 | And I got a little scared.
01:30:07.860 | I got a little scared.
01:30:09.160 | Is this the end of learning?
01:30:10.740 | Am I no longer learning if I'm not typing?
01:30:13.280 | And the way I, for me, recast that was I don't want to give up on the AI.
01:30:18.380 | It is such a better experience as a programmer to look up APIs, to get a second opinion on something, to do a draft.
01:30:27.960 | But I have to do the typing myself because you learn with your fingers.
01:30:31.840 | If you're learning how to play the guitar, you can watch as many YouTube videos as you want.
01:30:36.300 | You're not going to learn the guitar.
01:30:37.860 | You have to put your fingers on the strings to actually learn the motions.
01:30:43.800 | And I think there is a parallel here to programming, where programming has to be learned in part by the actual typing.
01:30:50.180 | I'm just really, this is fascinating.
01:30:52.780 | Listen, part of my brain agrees with you 100%, part doesn't.
01:30:59.020 | I think AI should be in the loop of learning.
01:31:01.720 | Now, current systems don't do that.
01:31:05.120 | But I think it's very possible for Cursor to say, to basically force you to type certain things.
01:31:12.460 | So, like, if you set the mode of learning, I just, I don't want to be this sort of give up on AI.
01:31:19.920 | I really, I think, I think vibe coding is a skill.
01:31:24.660 | So, for an experienced programmer, it's too easy to dismiss vibe coding as a thing.
01:31:30.580 | I agree.
01:31:31.280 | I wouldn't dismiss it.
01:31:32.120 | But I think you need to start building that skill and start to figure out how do you prevent the competency from slipping away from your fingers and brain.
01:31:42.500 | Like, how do you develop that skill in parallel to the other skill?
01:31:47.060 | I don't know.
01:31:48.240 | I just, I think it's a fascinating puzzle, though.
01:31:50.680 | I know too many really strong programmers that just kind of avoid AI because it's currently a little too dumb.
01:31:56.740 | Yes.
01:31:57.580 | It's a little too slow is actually my main problem.
01:31:59.740 | It's a little too dumb in some ways, but it's a little too slow in other ways.
01:32:02.840 | When I use Claude's code, the terminal version of Claude, which is actually my preferred way of using it, I just, I get too impatient.
01:32:13.980 | It feels like I'm going back to a time where code had to compile and I had to go do something else.
01:32:19.240 | A boil some tea while the code is compiling.
01:32:21.600 | Well, I've been working in Ruby for 20 years.
01:32:23.860 | I don't have compile weight in me anymore.
01:32:27.580 | So, there's that aspect of it.
01:32:29.740 | But I think the more crucial aspect for me is I really care about the competence.
01:32:33.740 | And I've seen what happens to even great programmers the moment they put away the keyboard.
01:32:39.760 | Because even before AI, this would happen as soon as people would get promoted.
01:32:43.760 | Most great programmers who work in large businesses stop writing code on a daily basis because they simply have too many meetings to attend to.
01:32:51.960 | They have too many other things to do.

01:32:57.520 | That doesn't mean they forget everything.

01:33:09.220 | I don't want that because I enjoy it too much.

01:51:16.400 | There should be more of the time writing from scratch.

01:51:25.320 | You're not going to learn how to play the guitar by watching YouTube guitar videos.
01:51:29.460 | You have to actually play yourself.

01:51:45.800 | Now, ironically, it seems AI is actually quite good at that.
01:51:48.380 | But humans are not.
01:51:49.600 | If you want to learn how to become a competent programmer, you have to program.
01:51:54.560 | It's really not that difficult to understand.
01:51:58.440 | Now, understand the temptation.
