01:52:10.640 | Or that you would take much longer to get at.
01:52:13.660 | But you're not going to learn anything.
01:52:15.060 | You're going to learn in this superficial way that feels like learning, but is completely empty calories.
01:52:21.620 | And secondly, if you can just vibe code it, you're not a programmer.
01:52:26.320 | Then anyone could do it, which may be wonderful.
01:52:28.960 | That's essentially what happened with the Access database.
01:52:31.460 | That's what happened with Excel.
01:52:32.920 | It took the capacity of accountants to become software developers because the tools became so accessible to them that they could build a model for how the business was going to do next week.
01:52:44.820 | That required a programmer prior to Excel.
01:52:47.300 | Now it didn't because they could do it themselves.
01:52:49.980 | Vibe coding enables non-programmers to explore their ideas in a way that I find absolutely wonderful.
01:52:59.340 | But it doesn't make you a programmer.
01:53:00.880 | I agree with you, but I want to allow for room for both of us to be wrong.
01:53:05.780 | For example, there could be vibe coding could actually be a skill that if you train it and by vibe coding, let's include the step of correction, the iterative correction.
01:53:18.120 | It's possible if you get really good at that, that you're outperforming the people that ride from scratch, that you can come up with truly innovative things, especially at this moment in history.
01:53:30.120 | While the LLMs are a little bit too dumb to create super novel things and a complete product, but they're starting to creep close to that.
01:53:38.640 | So if you're investing time now into becoming a really good vibe coder, maybe this is the right thing to do if it's indeed a skill.
01:53:48.440 | We kind of meme about vibe coding just like sitting back and it's in the name.
01:53:52.980 | But if you treat it seriously, a competitive vibe coder and get good at riding the wave of AI and get good at the skill of editing code versus writing code from scratch, it's possible that you can actually get farther in the long term.
01:54:12.080 | Maybe editing is a fundamentally different task than writing from scratch, if you take that seriously as a skill that you develop.
01:54:18.800 | To me, that's an open question.
01:54:21.200 | I just think I personally, and now you're on another level, but just me, just personally, I'm not as good at editing the code that I didn't write.
01:54:34.720 | No one is.
01:54:36.560 | No one is of this generation, but maybe that's a skill.
01:54:42.100 | Maybe if you get on the same page as the AI, because there's a consistency to the AI.
01:54:47.120 | It's like, it really is a pair programmer with a consistent style and structure and so on.
01:54:53.060 | Plus, with your own prompting, you can control the kind of code you write.
01:54:57.080 | I mean, it could legitimately be a skill.
01:54:58.700 | That's the dream of the prompt engineer.
01:55:00.740 | I think it's a complete pipe dream.
01:55:02.860 | I don't think editors exist that aren't good at writing.
01:55:08.500 | I've written a number of books.
01:55:09.780 | I've had a number of professional editors.
01:55:11.920 | Not all of them wrote their own great books, but all of them were great writers in some regard.
01:55:17.440 | You cannot give someone pointers if you don't know how to do it.
01:55:21.360 | It's very difficult for an editor to be able to spot what's wrong with a problem if they couldn't make the solution themselves.
01:55:30.400 | Editing, in my opinion, is the reward.
01:55:33.860 | The capacity to be a good editor is the reward you get from being a good doer.
01:55:38.660 | You have to be a doer first.
01:55:40.420 | Now, that's not the same as saying that vibe coding, prompt engineering, won't be able to produce fully formed, amazing systems even shortly.
01:55:51.680 | I think that's entirely possible.
01:55:53.040 | But then there's no skill left, which maybe is the greatest payoff at all.
01:55:57.400 | Wasn't that the whole promise of AI anyway?
01:55:59.340 | That it was just all natural language?
01:56:01.420 | That even my clumsy way of formulating a question could result in a beautiful, succinct answer?
01:56:07.500 | That actually, to me, is a much more appealing vision that there's going to be these special prompt engineering wizards
01:56:12.780 | who know how to tickle the AI just right to produce what they want.
01:56:16.980 | The beauty of AI is to think that someone who doesn't know the first thing about how AI actually works
01:56:23.480 | is able to formulate their idea and their aspirations for what they want,
01:56:28.280 | and the AI could somehow take that messy clump of ideas and produce something that someone wants.
01:56:34.640 | That's actually what programming has always been.
01:56:37.320 | There's very often been people who didn't know how to program, who wanted programs,
01:56:42.120 | who then hired programmers, who gave them messy descriptions of what they wanted,
01:56:46.140 | and then when the programmers delivered that back, said,
01:56:49.120 | oh, no, actually, that's not what I meant.
01:56:50.440 | I want something else.
01:56:51.460 | AI may be able to provide that cycle.
01:56:55.920 | If that happens to the fullest extent of it, yeah, there's not going to be as many programmers around, right?
01:57:00.760 | But hopefully, presumably, someone still, at least for the foreseeable future,
01:57:06.300 | have to understand whether what the AI is producing actually works or not.
01:57:10.880 | As an interesting case study, maybe a thought experiment,
01:57:14.260 | if I wanted to vibe code Basecamp or Hay and some of the products you've built,
01:57:23.120 | like what would be the bottlenecks?
01:57:26.320 | Where would I fail along the way?
01:57:28.880 | What I've seen when I've been trying to do this, trying to use vibe coding to build something real,
01:57:33.840 | is you actually fail really early.
01:57:36.600 | The vibe coding is able to build a veneer at the current present moment of something that looks like it works,
01:57:43.260 | but it's flawed in all sorts of ways.
01:57:45.040 | There are the obvious ways, the meme ways, that it's leaking all your API keys.
01:57:49.100 | It's storing your password in plain text.
01:57:52.120 | I think that's ultimately solvable.
01:57:54.560 | It's going to figure that out, or at least it's going to get better at that.
01:57:58.000 | But its capacity to get lost in its own labyrinth is very great right now.
01:58:02.540 | You let it code something, and then you want to change something,
01:58:06.820 | and it becomes a game of whack-a-mole real quick.
01:58:08.920 | Peter Levels, who've been doing this wonderful flight simulator, was talking to that,
01:58:12.660 | where at a certain scale, the thing just keeps biting its own tail.
01:58:16.340 | You want to fix something, and it breaks five other things,
01:58:18.720 | which I think is actually uniquely human, because that's how most bad programmers are.
01:58:22.860 | At the certain level of complexity with the domain, they can't fix one thing without breaking three other things.
01:58:29.960 | So in that way, I'm actually, in some way, it's almost a positive signal for that the AI is going to figure this out,
01:58:36.080 | because it's on an extremely human trajectory right now.
01:58:39.220 | The kind of mistakes it's making are the kind of mistakes that junior programmers make all the time.
01:58:43.460 | Yeah.
01:58:43.800 | Can we zoom out and look at the vision, the manifesto, the doctrine of Rails?
01:58:51.160 | What are some of the things that make a programming language, a framework, great, especially for web development?
01:58:58.340 | So we talked about happiness.
01:58:59.660 | Yes.
01:59:00.360 | The underlying objective of Ruby.
01:59:02.660 | What else?
01:59:04.280 | So you're looking at the nine points I wrote out in, I think, 2012.
01:59:08.140 | And first, before we dive into them, I want to say the reason I wrote it down is that
01:59:13.280 | if you want a community to endure, you have to record its values and you have to record its practices.
01:59:20.820 | If you don't, eventually you're going to get enough new people come in who have their own ideas of where this thing should go.
01:59:27.500 | And if we don't have a guiding light helping us to make decisions, we're going to start flailing.
01:59:34.400 | We're going to start actually falling apart.
01:59:35.960 | I think this is one of the key reasons that institutions of all kinds start falling apart.
01:59:40.180 | We forget why Chesterton's fence is there.
01:59:43.560 | We just go like, why is that fence there?
01:59:45.240 | Let's yank it out.
01:59:46.480 | Oh, it was to keep the wolves out.
01:59:48.140 | Now we're all dead.
01:59:49.080 | Oops.
01:59:49.680 | So I wanted to write these things down.
01:59:52.420 | And if we just take them quick one by one, you talked about optimizing for programmer happiness.
01:59:56.820 | I put that at number one in homage of Matt's.
02:00:00.240 | And that's a lot about accepting that there is occasionally a trade-off between writing beautiful code and other things we want out of systems.
02:00:07.120 | There could be a runtime trade-off.
02:00:08.640 | There can be a performance trade-off.
02:00:10.300 | But we're going to do it nonetheless.
02:00:12.920 | We're also going to allow ambiguity in a way that many programmers by default are uncomfortable with.
02:00:20.360 | I give the example actually here of in the interactive Ruby shell, where you can play with the language or even interact with your domain model.
02:00:28.860 | You can quit it in two ways, at least, that I found.
02:00:32.660 | You can write exit.
02:00:33.740 | Boom, you're out of the program.
02:00:35.440 | You can write quit.
02:00:36.740 | Boom, you're out of the program.
02:00:37.920 | They do the same thing.
02:00:39.100 | We just wrote both exit, or the people who built that, wrote both exit and quit because they knew humans were likely to pick one or the other.
02:00:45.180 | Python is the perfect contrast to this.
02:00:49.040 | In the Python interactive protocol, if you write exit, it won't exit.
02:00:53.660 | It'll give you a fucking lesson.
02:00:54.860 | It'll basically tell you to read the fucking manual.
02:00:57.820 | It says, use exit parentheses or control D, i.e. end of file, to exit.
02:01:06.060 | I'm like, one is very human, and another is very engineer.
02:01:10.940 | And I mean that, both of them, in the best possible way.
02:01:14.220 | Python is pedantic.
02:01:16.320 | Python's value, from the start stated, is that there should be preferably one and only one way to do a certain thing.
02:01:25.960 | Ruby goes the complete opposite.
02:01:27.620 | No, we want the full expression that fits different human brains, such that it seems like the language is guessing just what they want.
02:01:36.900 | And part of that is also you described the principle of least surprise, which is a difficult thing to engineer into a language, because you have to kind of, it's a subjective thing.
02:01:46.940 | Which is why you can't do it in one way, which is why I use the example of both exit and quit.
02:01:50.560 | The principle of least surprise for some people would be like, oh, exit, that's how I get out of the prompt.
02:01:56.580 | For other people, it'd be quit.
02:01:58.000 | Why don't we just do both?
02:02:00.000 | Okay, so what's the convention over configuration?
02:02:03.500 | That's a big one.
02:02:04.940 | That's a big one.
02:02:05.880 | That's a huge one.
02:02:06.600 | And it was born out of a frustration I had in the early days with especially Java frameworks, where when you were setting up a web application framework for Java back in the day, it was not uncommon to literally write hundreds, if not thousands of lines of XML configuration files.
02:02:22.640 | Oh, I need this.
02:02:23.800 | I want the database to use the foreign keys as post underscore ID.
02:02:29.800 | No, no, no.
02:02:30.120 | I want it as post capital I-D.
02:02:33.380 | Oh, no, no, no.
02:02:34.340 | You have to do a capital P-I-D.
02:02:36.720 | There are all these ways where you can configure how foreign relation keys should work in a database, and none of them matter.
02:02:43.300 | We just need to pick one, and then that's fine.
02:02:46.380 | And if we pick one and we can depend on it, it becomes a convention.
02:02:50.240 | And if it's a convention, we don't have to configure it.
02:02:52.820 | And if we don't have to configure it, you can get started with what you actually care about much quicker.
02:02:57.660 | So convention over configuration is essentially to take that idea that the system should come pre-assembled.
02:03:03.740 | I'm not just handing you a box of fucking Legos and asking you to build the Millennium Falcon.
02:03:08.360 | I'm giving you a finished toy.
02:03:10.180 | You can edit.
02:03:10.880 | You can change it.
02:03:11.600 | It's still built out of Legos.
02:03:12.700 | You can still take some pieces off and put in some other pieces.
02:03:15.140 | But I'm giving you the final product.
02:03:16.780 | And this cuts against the grain of what most programmers love.
02:03:20.680 | They love a box of Legos.
02:03:22.100 | They love to put everything together from scratch.
02:03:24.600 | They love to make all these detailed little decisions that just don't matter at all.
02:03:28.220 | And I want to elevate that up such that, hey, I'm not trying to take the decisions away from you.
02:03:32.460 | I just want you to focus on decisions that actually matter, that you truly care about.
02:03:37.080 | No one cares about whether it's post underscore ID or post ID or PIT.
02:03:41.240 | Yeah, great defaults.
02:03:43.240 | Yes.
02:03:43.980 | It's just a wonderful thing.
02:03:45.140 | You have all these aspirations.
02:03:46.600 | They're going to do some kind of custom, most beautiful Legos castle that nobody's ever built from these pieces.
02:03:52.500 | But in reality, to be productive in most situations, you just need to build the basic thing.
02:03:59.100 | And then on top of that is where your creativity comes.
02:04:03.240 | Absolutely.
02:04:03.560 | And I think this is one of those part of the doctrine that a lot of programmers who get to use Ruby on Rails begrudgingly will acknowledge it's a nice thing, even if they don't really like it.
02:04:16.160 | Like, it's hard to beat the sort of attraction to building with Legos from scratch out of programmers.
02:04:23.360 | That's just what we like.
02:04:24.420 | Like, this is why we're programmers in the first place, because we'd like to put these little pieces together.
02:04:27.720 | But we can direct that instinct towards a more productive end of the stack.
02:04:32.920 | Okay.
02:04:33.740 | What are some of the other ones?
02:04:34.880 | The menu is omakasa.
02:04:37.300 | It actually comes out of the same principle, that great defaults really matter.
02:04:41.640 | If you look at everything that's wrong with the JavaScript ecosystem right now, for example, it is that no one is in charge of the menu.
02:04:49.160 | There are a billion different dishes, and you can configure just your tailored, specific configuration of it.
02:04:55.900 | But no one done the work to make sure it all fits together.
02:04:58.780 | So you have all these unique problems in the JavaScript ecosystem, for example.
02:05:02.460 | There's probably 25 major ways of just doing the controller layer.
02:05:07.280 | And then as many of how to talk to the database.
02:05:10.560 | So you get this permutation of N times N times N of no one is using the same thing.
02:05:16.880 | And if they are using the same thing, they're only using the same thing for about five minutes.
02:05:19.960 | So we have no retained wisdom.
02:05:22.640 | We build up no durable skills.
02:05:25.160 | Rails goes the complete opposite way of saying, do you know what?
02:05:28.740 | Rails is not just a web framework.
02:05:31.360 | It is a complete attempt at solving the web problem.
02:05:35.500 | It's a complete attempt at solving everything you need to build a great web application.
02:05:40.400 | And every piece of that puzzle should ideally be in the box, pre-configured, pre-assembled.
02:05:47.920 | If you want to change some of those pieces later, that's wonderful.
02:05:50.520 | But on day one, you'll get a full menu designed by a chef who really cared about every piece of the ingredient.
02:05:58.380 | And you're going to enjoy it.
02:06:02.040 | And that's, again, one of those things where many programmers think, like, I know better.
02:06:06.880 | And they do in some hyper-local sense of it.
02:06:10.820 | Every programmer knows better.
02:06:12.020 | This is what Ruby is built on.
02:06:13.420 | That every programmer knows better in their specific situation.
02:06:16.760 | Maybe they can do something dangerous.
02:06:18.620 | Maybe they think they know better.
02:06:20.820 | And then they blow their foot off.
02:06:22.220 | And then they truly will know better because they've blown their foot off once and won't do it again.
02:06:26.640 | So you, in general, see the value in the monolith.
02:06:32.640 | Yes.
02:06:33.100 | The integrated system.
02:06:34.700 | Integrated system.
02:06:35.420 | Someone thought of the whole problem.
02:06:37.260 | This is one of the reasons why I've been on a crusade against microservices since the term was coined.
02:06:43.200 | Microservices was born out of essentially a good idea.
02:06:47.160 | What do you do at Netflix scale when you have thousands of engineers working on millions of lines of code?
02:06:53.080 | No one can keep that entire system in their head at one time.
02:06:55.820 | You have to break it down.
02:06:56.860 | Microservices can be a reasonable way to do that when you're at Netflix scale.
02:07:00.860 | When you apply that pattern to a team of 20 programmers working on a code base of half a million lines of code, you're an idiot.
02:07:07.880 | You just don't need to turn method invocations into network calls.
02:07:14.220 | It is the first rule of distributed programming.
02:07:16.940 | Do not distribute your programming.
02:07:19.580 | It makes everything harder.
02:07:21.960 | All the failure conditions you have to consider as a programmer just becomes infinitely harder when there's a network cable involved.
02:07:27.980 | So I hate the idea of premature decomposition.
02:07:32.640 | And microservices is exactly that.
02:07:35.040 | The monolith says, let's try to focus on building a whole system that a single human can actually understand and push that paradigm as far as possible by compressing all the concepts such that more of it will fit into memory of a single operating human.
02:07:49.960 | And then we can have a system where I can actually understand all of Basecamp.
02:07:53.460 | I can actually understand all of Hay.
02:07:55.300 | Both of those systems are just over 100,000 lines of code.
02:07:58.620 | I've seen people do this at maybe twice, maybe three times that scale, and then it starts breaking down.
02:08:02.720 | Once you get north of certainly half a million lines of code, no individual human can do it.
02:08:07.840 | And that's when you get into maybe some degree of microservices can make sense.
02:08:11.380 | Basecamp and Hay are both 100,000?
02:08:13.820 | 100,000 lines of code.
02:08:15.000 | Wow, that's small.
02:08:16.140 | It is.
02:08:16.900 | Considering the fact that Basecamp, I think, has something like 420 screens, different ways and configurations.
02:08:23.180 | Do you include the front end in that?
02:08:25.020 | No, that's the Ruby code.
02:08:26.680 | Well, it's front end in the sense that some of that Ruby code is beneficial to the front end.
02:08:30.640 | But it's not JavaScript, for example.
02:08:32.360 | Now, the other thing we might talk about later is we write very little JavaScript, actually, for all of our applications.
02:08:37.540 | Hay, which is a Gmail competitor, Gmail ships, I think, 28 megabytes of uncompressed JavaScript.
02:08:44.340 | If you compress it, I think it's about 6 megabytes, 28 megabytes.
02:08:46.960 | Think about how many lines of code that is.
02:08:48.480 | When Hay launched, we shipped 40 kilobytes.
02:08:51.920 | It's trying to solve the same problem.
02:08:54.700 | You can solve the email client problem with either 28 megabytes of uncompressed JavaScript or with 40 kilobytes.
02:09:02.180 | If you do things differently.
02:09:03.600 | But that comes to the same problem, essentially.
02:09:06.480 | This is why I have fiercely fought splitting front end and back end apart.
02:09:12.060 | That, in my opinion, this was one of the great crimes against web development.
02:09:16.540 | That we are still atoning for.
02:09:19.940 | That we separated and divided what was and should be a unified problem-solving mechanism.
02:09:27.440 | When you are working both on front end and back end, you understand the whole system.
02:09:31.520 | And you're not going to get into these camps that decompose and eventually you end up with shit like GraphQL.
02:09:36.640 | Okay.
02:09:38.920 | Let's fly through the rest of the doctrine.
02:09:42.720 | No one paradigm.
02:09:43.840 | No one paradigm goes to the fact that Ruby is a fiercely object-oriented programming language at its core.
02:09:49.380 | But it's also a functional programming language.
02:09:52.040 | This five times I told you about, you can essentially do these anonymous function calls.
02:09:58.760 | And you can chain them together very much in the spirit of how true functional programming languages work.
02:10:04.100 | Ruby has even moved closer towards the functional programming end of the scale by making strings immutable.
02:10:11.340 | There are ideas from all different disciplines of, and all different paradigms of software development that can fit together.
02:10:17.920 | Smalltalk, for example, was only object-oriented.
02:10:21.680 | And that was just it.
02:10:22.660 | Ruby tries to be mainly object-oriented, but borrow a little bit of functional programming, a little bit of imperative programming.
02:10:28.660 | Be able to do all of that.
02:10:29.900 | Rails tries to do the same thing.
02:10:32.040 | We're not just going to pick one paradigm and run it through everything.
02:10:35.180 | Object-orientation is at the center of it, but it's okay to invite all these other disciplines in.
02:10:40.700 | It's okay to be inspired.
02:10:41.860 | It's okay to remix it.
02:10:43.080 | I actually think one of the main benefits of Rails is that it's a remix.
02:10:48.420 | I didn't invent all these ideas.
02:10:50.300 | I didn't come up with active record.
02:10:52.220 | I didn't come up with the MVC way of dividing an application.
02:10:56.020 | I took all the great ideas that I had learned and picked up from every different camp, and I put it together.
02:11:02.020 | Not because there was going to be just one single overarching theory of everything, but I was going to have a cohesive unit that incorporated the best from everywhere.
02:11:09.860 | Is that idea a bit at tension with the beauty of the monolith system?
02:11:14.860 | I think the monolith can be thought of as quite roomy, quite as a big tent, that the monolith needs, actually, to borrow a little bit of functional programming for the kinds of problems that that excels, that discipline excels at solving, and that paradigm excels at solving.
02:11:32.460 | If you also want object-orientation at its core, I actually think when I've looked at functional programming languages, there's a lot to love.
02:11:39.980 | And then I see some of the crazy contortions they have to go through when part of the problem they're solving calls for mutating something.
02:11:49.160 | And you go like, holy shit, this is a great paradigm for 90% of the problem.
02:11:55.680 | And then you're twisting yourself completely out of shape when you try to solve the last 10.
02:11:59.700 | Ooh, exalt beautiful code is the next one.
02:12:02.680 | We've talked about that at length, and here's a great example that really summarizes the domain-specific language quality of Ruby on Rails, that you can make code actually pleasant to write and read, which is really funny to me because, as we talked about, when I started learning programming, it wasn't even a consideration.
02:12:20.920 | I didn't even know that that could be part of the premise, that that could be part of the solution, that writing code could feel as good as writing a poem.
02:12:30.720 | Class project, application record belongs to account, has many participants, class name person, validates presence of name.
02:12:40.440 | See, you could read it out.
02:12:42.380 | You didn't even change anything.
02:12:44.080 | It's like a haiku or something.
02:12:45.440 | Right.
02:12:45.740 | Isn't that beautiful?
02:12:47.060 | Yeah, it's nice.
02:12:47.620 | It's really nice.
02:12:49.780 | There's an intuitive nature to it.
02:12:51.560 | Okay, so I have specific questions there.
02:12:54.380 | I mean, active record, just to take that tangent, that has to be your favorite feature.
02:12:59.720 | It's the crown jewel of Rails.
02:13:02.540 | It really is.
02:13:03.420 | It is the defining characteristic of how to work with Ruby on Rails.
02:13:07.660 | And it's born in an interesting level of controversy because it actually uses a pattern that had been described by Martin Fowler in the Patterns of Enterprise Application Architecture, one of the greatest books for anyone working on business systems.
02:13:23.420 | And if you had not read it, you must pick it up immediately.
02:13:25.760 | Patterns of Enterprise Application Architecture.
02:13:28.440 | I think it was published in 2001.
02:13:30.120 | It is one of the very few programming books that I have read many times over.
02:13:35.020 | It's incredible.
02:13:36.180 | In it, Martin describes a bunch of different patterns of how to build business systems, essentially.
02:13:42.640 | And active record is a little bit of a footnote in there.
02:13:45.500 | The pattern is literally called active record.
02:13:47.140 | You can look it up.
02:13:47.680 | Nice.
02:13:48.020 | It's called active record.
02:13:48.840 | I wasn't even creative enough to come up with a name of my own.
02:13:52.420 | But it allows the creation, the marriage of database and object orientation in a way that a lot of programmers find a little off-putting.
02:14:03.480 | They don't actually want to pollute the beautiful object-oriented nature of that kind of programming with SQL.
02:14:11.620 | There was a rant by Uncle Bob the other day about how SQL is the worst thing ever.
02:14:16.220 | Blah, blah.
02:14:17.100 | Okay, fine.
02:14:18.920 | Whatever.
02:14:19.360 | I don't care.
02:14:20.120 | This is practical.
02:14:22.160 | We are making crud applications.
02:14:24.360 | You're taking things out of an HTML form and you're sticking them into a damn database.
02:14:28.440 | It's not more complicated than that.
02:14:29.940 | The more abstractions you put in between those two ends of the spectrum, the more you're just fooling yourself.
02:14:35.980 | This is what we're doing.
02:14:36.980 | We're talking to SQL databases.
02:14:39.140 | By the way, quick aside, SQL was one of those things that have endured the onslaught of no SQL databases, structured list data for a better part of a decade and still reign supreme.
02:14:50.240 | SQL was a good thing to invest your time in learning.
02:14:52.960 | Every program I'm working with the web should know SQL to a fair degree, even if they're working with an ORM, an object relational mapper, as active record.
02:15:02.300 | You still need to understand SQL.
02:15:04.260 | What active record does is not so much try to abstract the SQL away behind a different kind of paradigm.
02:15:10.320 | It's just making it less cumbersome to write, making it more amenable to build domain models on top of other domain models in a way since you don't have to write every damn SQL statement by hand.
02:15:23.100 | Let's just say that active record is an ORM, which is a layer that makes it intuitive and human interpretable to communicate with a database.
02:15:33.220 | Even simpler than that, it turns tables into classes and rows into objects.
02:15:39.160 | I actually think SQL is very easy to understand.
02:15:41.940 | Most of it, you can write some SQL golf too.
02:15:44.100 | That's very hard to understand.
02:15:45.340 | But SQL at its base and much of the criticism against SQL was it was written for human consumption.
02:15:50.580 | It's actually quite verbose, especially if you're doing things like inserts over and over again.
02:15:55.360 | It's quite verbose, insert into table, parentheses, enumerate every column you want to insert, values, parentheses, every value that fits with that column.
02:16:05.420 | It gets tedious to write SQL by hand, but it's actually very humanly readable.
02:16:12.000 | Active record just takes that tediousness away.
02:16:15.180 | It makes it possible to combine things in a way that a humanly describable language just doesn't.
02:16:20.940 | It composes things into methods and you can combine these methods and you can build structures around them.
02:16:25.360 | So I don't dislike SQL.
02:16:27.480 | I dislike a lot of things in programming.
02:16:29.080 | I try to get rid of them.
02:16:30.380 | SQL wasn't really one of them.
02:16:31.720 | It was just a sense of I don't want to write the same thing over and over again.
02:16:35.520 | It was a can we be a little more succinct?
02:16:37.880 | Can we match it just slightly better to the object orientation without trying to hide away the fact that we're persisting these objects into a database?
02:16:47.120 | That's where I think a lot of ORMs went wrong.
02:16:50.120 | They tried to live in the pure world of objects, never to consider that those objects had to be consistent into a SQL database.
02:16:58.200 | And then they came up with convoluted way of translating back and forth.
02:17:01.900 | Active record says, do you know what?
02:17:04.140 | Just accept it.
02:17:04.840 | This record, this object, is not going to get saved into some NoSQL database.
02:17:09.700 | It's not going to be saved.
02:17:10.480 | It's going to be saved into a SQL database.
02:17:11.920 | So it's just structured the whole thing around that.
02:17:14.420 | It's going to have attributes.
02:17:15.820 | Those attributes are going to respond to columns in the database.
02:17:19.000 | It's not more complicated than that.
02:17:20.500 | Stop making it so.
02:17:21.420 | Yeah, but I should say, so I personally love SQL because I'm an algorithms person.
02:17:27.180 | And so I love optimization.
02:17:28.360 | I love to know how the databases actually work so I can match the SQL queries and the design of the tables such that there is, you know, optimal, squeeze the optimal performance out of the table.
02:17:42.140 | Okay.
02:17:42.780 | Based on the actual way that that table is used.
02:17:46.140 | So, I mean, I think that pushes to the point that, like, there is value in learning and understanding SQL.
02:17:52.100 | I wonder, because I started looking at Active Record and it looks really awesome.
02:17:58.340 | Does that make you lazy?
02:18:00.020 | Not you, but a person that rolls in and starts using Rails.
02:18:06.140 | You can probably get away with never really learning SQL, right?
02:18:09.720 | As long as you want to stay at the entry level of competence.
02:18:12.740 | And this is actually my overarching mission with Rails, is to lower the barrier of entry so far down that someone can start seeing stuff on the browser without basically understanding anything.
02:18:26.260 | They can run Rails' new blog, run a couple of generators.
02:18:31.260 | They have a whole system.
02:18:32.400 | They don't understand anything.
02:18:33.720 | But it's an invitation to learn more.
02:18:36.460 | Where I get fired up, and this ties back to the AI discussion, is when that's turned into this meme that programmers no longer have to be competent.
02:18:44.520 | They can just, I mean, the AI is going to figure it out.
02:18:47.420 | The generators is going to figure it out.
02:18:48.860 | I don't need to know SQL.
02:18:50.200 | Active Record is going to abstract it away from me.
02:18:52.240 | No, no, no.
02:18:52.680 | Dude, hold up.
02:18:54.540 | The path here is competence.
02:18:56.600 | I'm trying to teach you things.
02:18:58.340 | I understand I can't teach you everything in five minutes.
02:19:00.880 | No one who's ever become good at anything worthwhile could be taught everything in five minutes.
02:19:06.100 | If you want to be a fully well-rounded web application developer, that takes years.
02:19:11.600 | But you can actually become somewhat productive in a few days.
02:19:16.680 | You can have fun in a few days for sure.
02:19:18.100 | You can have fun in a few minutes and a few hours.
02:19:20.440 | And over time, I can teach you a little more.
02:19:22.880 | Active Record says, like, yeah, yeah, all right.
02:19:25.180 | Start to here.
02:19:26.160 | And then, like, next week, we'll do a class on SQL.
02:19:29.580 | And actually, you have this beautiful expression that I love, that a great programming language like Ruby has a soft RAM, but the RAM goes to infinity.
02:19:38.640 | That's exactly right.
02:19:39.720 | So, yeah, it's super accessible, super easy to get started.
02:19:43.080 | And it never stops.
02:19:44.100 | Yeah.
02:19:44.360 | There's always more to learn.
02:19:45.960 | This is one of the reasons I'm still having fun programming, that I'm still learning new things.
02:19:50.240 | I can still incorporate new things.
02:19:51.420 | The web is deep enough as a domain.
02:19:53.180 | You're never going to learn all of it.
02:19:55.660 | Provide sharp knives.
02:19:57.380 | This is a good one.
02:19:58.500 | Because another way of saying this, the opposite way of saying this, the Java way of saying this, do not provide foot guns.
02:20:05.200 | Right?
02:20:05.860 | I don't want to give you sharp knives.
02:20:08.000 | You're a child.
02:20:09.100 | You can't handle a sharp knife.
02:20:10.400 | Here's a dull butter knife.
02:20:11.960 | Cut your damn steak.
02:20:13.080 | Right?
02:20:13.760 | That's a very frustrating experience.
02:20:15.240 | You want a sharp knife, even though you might be able to cut yourself.
02:20:18.280 | I trust humans in the same way that mats trust humans.
02:20:22.620 | Maybe you cut off a finger.
02:20:24.780 | All right.
02:20:25.440 | You're not going to do that again.
02:20:26.360 | Thankfully, it was a virtual finger.
02:20:28.320 | It's going to grow back out.
02:20:29.680 | Your competence is going to grow.
02:20:31.720 | It's more fun to work with sharp tools.
02:20:34.660 | And that actually contributes to the ramp that goes to infinity.
02:20:38.040 | To the learning.
02:20:39.140 | Value integrated systems.
02:20:41.260 | We kind of hit on that one.
02:20:42.720 | This is, Rails is trying to solve the whole problem of the web.
02:20:45.260 | Not just one little component.
02:20:46.960 | It's not leaving you a bunch of pieces you have to put together yourself.
02:20:50.360 | Progress over stability.
02:20:51.960 | You know what?
02:20:52.820 | If there's one that's dated, it's probably that one.
02:20:55.020 | At this stage, Rails has been incredibly stable over many, many generations.
02:21:01.260 | The last major release, Rails 8, was basically a no-op upgrade for anyone running Rails 7.
02:21:08.120 | Rails 7 was almost a no-op upgrade for anyone running Rails 6.
02:21:12.260 | I used to think it required more churn to get progress, to stay on the leading edge of new stuff.
02:21:20.500 | And I wrote this before I experienced the indignity of the 2010s in the JavaScript community.
02:21:27.920 | Where it seemed like stability was not just unvalued, it was actually despised.
02:21:34.340 | That churn in and of itself was a value we should be pursuing.
02:21:38.340 | That if you were still working with the same framework three months later, you were an idiot.
02:21:42.660 | And I saw that, and I actually recoiled.
02:21:44.940 | And if I was going to write the doctrine today, I'd write that differently.
02:21:48.140 | I wouldn't say progress over stability.
02:21:49.700 | Well, maybe it'd be a function of the age of the programming language also.
02:21:54.800 | Maybe, or a deeper understanding of the problem.
02:21:58.960 | I think part of what's so fascinating about technology is that we have this perception
02:22:02.900 | that everything constantly moves so fast.
02:22:05.920 | No, it doesn't.
02:22:07.420 | Everything moves at a glacial pace.
02:22:09.640 | There is occasionally a paradigm shift, like what's happening with AI right now, like what
02:22:16.400 | happened with the introduction of the iPhone in 2007, like what happened with the internet
02:22:21.240 | in 95.
02:22:21.800 | That's basically the total sum of my career.
02:22:24.200 | Three things changed.
02:22:25.940 | Everything else in between was incremental, small improvements.
02:22:31.060 | You can recognize a Rails application written in 2003.
02:22:35.020 | I know, because the base camp I wrote back then is still operating, making millions of
02:22:40.040 | dollars in ARR, servings and customers on the initial version that was launched back then.
02:22:44.320 | And it looks like the Rails code, if I squint a little, that I would write today.
02:22:48.000 | So most things don't change, even in computing.
02:22:51.460 | And that's actually a good thing.
02:22:52.480 | We saw with the JavaScript ecosystem what happens when everyone gets just mad about constant
02:22:57.920 | churn.
02:22:58.360 | Things don't change that often.
02:23:00.000 | By the way, on that small tangent, you just sort of visibly verbally changed your mind with
02:23:06.920 | the you of 15 years ago.
02:23:09.780 | That's interesting.
02:23:11.420 | Have you noticed yourself changing your mind quite a bit over the years?
02:23:16.340 | I would say, oh, yes.
02:23:19.400 | And then also, oh, no, in the sense that there are absolutely fundamental things, both about
02:23:24.360 | human nature, about institutions, about programming, about business that I've changed my mind on.
02:23:29.860 | And then I've also had experiences that are almost even more interesting, where I thought
02:23:34.500 | I had changed my mind.
02:23:35.980 | And I tried it a new way, realized why I had the original opinion in the first place,
02:23:40.660 | and then gone back to it.
02:23:42.020 | So it happens both ways.
02:23:43.940 | An example of the later part, for example, was managers at 37 Signals.
02:23:49.120 | For the longest time, I would rail against engineering managers as an unnecessary burden on a small
02:23:57.100 | or even medium-sized company.
02:23:58.300 | And at one point, I actually started doubting myself a little bit.
02:24:01.300 | I started thinking, like, you know what?
02:24:03.500 | Maybe all programmers do need a one-on-one therapy session every week with their engineering
02:24:08.480 | manager to be a whole individual.
02:24:10.820 | So we tried that for a couple of years, where we hired some very good engineering managers
02:24:15.200 | who did engineering management the way you're supposed to do it, the way it's done all over
02:24:19.460 | the place.
02:24:19.840 | And after that, I thought, like, no.
02:24:22.780 | No, I was right.
02:24:24.340 | This was correct.
02:24:25.380 | We should not have had managers.
02:24:27.240 | Not every programmer needs a therapy session with an engineering manager every week.
02:24:31.680 | We don't need these endlessly scheduled huddles.
02:24:34.880 | We don't need all these meetings.
02:24:36.340 | We just need to leave people the hell alone to work on problems that they enjoy for long
02:24:41.640 | stretches of uninterrupted time.
02:24:43.280 | That is where happiness is found.
02:24:45.700 | That's where productivity is found.
02:24:47.180 | And if you can get away with it, you absolutely should.
02:24:50.240 | Engineering management is a necessary evil when that breaks down.
02:24:54.960 | What's the case for managers then?
02:24:56.760 | The case for managers is that if you do have a lot of people, there's a bunch of work that
02:25:01.460 | kind of just crops up.
02:25:02.660 | The one-on-one is one example that programmers need someone to check in with.
02:25:06.260 | There's another idealized version that someone needs to guide the career of juniors, for example,
02:25:11.640 | to give them redirecting feedback and all this other stuff.
02:25:14.760 | And it's not that in the abstract, I don't agree with some of those things.
02:25:19.960 | But in practice, I've found that they often create more problems that they solve.
02:25:25.660 | And a good example here is, can you get feedback from someone who's not better at your job than
02:25:32.460 | you are?
02:25:32.800 | You can get some feedback.
02:25:34.300 | You can get feedback on how you show up at work.
02:25:36.440 | Are you being courteous to others?
02:25:38.920 | Are you being a good communicator?
02:25:40.380 | Okay, yes.
02:25:41.500 | But you can't get feedback on your work.
02:25:43.020 | And that's more important.
02:25:43.760 | It's more important that you work under and with someone who's better at your job than you
02:25:49.020 | are if you wish to progress in your career.
02:25:51.160 | And every single programmer I've ever worked with was far more interested in progressing in
02:25:55.440 | their career on that metric, getting better at their craft, than they were in picking up
02:26:01.000 | pointers that a middle manager could teach them.
02:26:04.200 | That's not saying that there isn't value in it.
02:26:06.300 | It's not saying there isn't value in being a better person or a better communicator.
02:26:09.480 | Of course, there is all those things.
02:26:10.480 | But if I have to choose one or the other, I value competence higher.
02:26:15.120 | Like that's, again, I caveat this a million times because I know what people sometimes hear.
02:26:20.900 | They hear the genius asshole is just fine and that's great and you should excuse all sorts of
02:26:27.120 | malicious behavior if someone's just really good at what they do.
02:26:29.980 | I'm not saying that at all.
02:26:31.120 | What I am saying is that the history of competence is a history of learning from people who are better
02:26:36.580 | than you.
02:26:37.380 | And that relationship should take precedence over all else.
02:26:41.360 | And that relationship gets put aside a bit when engineering managers are introduced.
02:26:46.560 | Now, the funny thing is, this conversation ties back to the earlier things we were talking about.
02:26:51.260 | Most engineering managers are actually former programmers.
02:26:53.900 | They at least know programming to some extent.
02:26:55.940 | But what I've seen time and again is that they lose their touch, their feel with it very, very quickly
02:27:02.420 | and turn into pointy haired bosses very, very quickly.
02:27:06.960 | Who are really good at checking for updates, just seeing where we are on Project A here.
02:27:12.800 | If you need anything or are we ready to deliver to it?
02:27:15.120 | Okay.
02:27:15.540 | Yes.
02:27:16.900 | And also, no.
02:27:17.980 | Just shut up.
02:27:19.120 | Leave me the hell alone.
02:27:20.280 | Let me program.
02:27:21.280 | And then I'll come up for air.
02:27:22.640 | I'll talk with other programmers who I can spar with.
02:27:26.140 | And we can learn something with.
02:27:27.140 | I can turn the problems over with.
02:27:28.440 | And we can move forward.
02:27:29.740 | If you look back on the history of computer industry, all the great innovation that's happened,
02:27:35.380 | it's all been done by tiny teams with no engineering managers, just full of highly skilled individuals.
02:27:43.400 | You've had John Carmich on here.
02:27:46.580 | I used to look up to id Software so much, not just because I love Quake, not just because I loved what they were doing,
02:27:52.120 | but because he shared a bit about how the company worked.
02:27:55.060 | There were no managers.
02:27:56.280 | Or maybe they had one business guy doing some business stuff, but that was just to get paid.
02:28:00.100 | Everything else was basically just designers and programmers.
02:28:03.000 | And there were about eight of them.
02:28:04.420 | And they created a goddamn Quake 2.
02:28:06.020 | So why do you need all these people again?
02:28:08.740 | Why do you need all these managers again?
02:28:10.700 | I think, again, at a certain scale, it does break down.
02:28:15.340 | It's hard to just have 100,000 programmers running around wild without any product mommies or daddies telling them what to do.
02:28:22.860 | I understand that.
02:28:23.740 | And then even as I say that, I also don't understand it.
02:28:26.440 | Because if you look at something like Gmail, for example, there was like a side project done by Boucher at Google at the time.
02:28:33.380 | So much of the enduring long-term value of even all these huge companies were created by people who didn't have a goddamn manager.
02:28:40.720 | And that's not an accident.
02:28:42.280 | That's a direct cause and effect.
02:28:44.820 | So I've turned in some way even more militant over the years against this notion of management, at least for myself and knowing who I am and how I want to work.
02:28:52.860 | Because the other part of this is I don't want to be a manager.
02:28:55.780 | And maybe this is just me projecting the fact that I'm an introvert who don't like to talk to people in one-on-one calls every week.
02:29:02.340 | But it also encapsulates how I was able to progress my career.
02:29:06.420 | I did not really go to the next level with Ruby or otherwise until I had a door I could close and no one could bother me for six hours straight.
02:29:14.500 | So in companies, probably one of the reasons is it's very easy to hire managers.
02:29:20.400 | And managers also delegate responsibility from you.
02:29:27.460 | So if you just have a bunch of programmers running around, it's work.
02:29:33.100 | It's intellectual work to have to deal with the first principles of every problem that's going on.
02:29:38.840 | So managers, you can relax.
02:29:41.640 | Oh, it'll be taken care of.
02:29:43.960 | But they then hire their own managers and it just multiplies and multiplies and multiplies.
02:29:48.900 | I would love it if some of the great companies we have in the United States, if there was like an extra side branch that we could always run.
02:29:58.920 | Maybe physicists can come up how to split the simulation to where just all the managers are removed.
02:30:04.940 | Also, just with it, just in that branch, just the PR and the comms people also, and even the lawyers, just the engineers.
02:30:12.900 | And let's just see.
02:30:14.360 | And then we merge it back.
02:30:16.440 | I've essentially run that branch at 37 Singles for 20 years.
02:30:19.160 | And I've experimented with forking back on the other side.
02:30:22.720 | I've experimented with having a full-time lawyer on staff.
02:30:25.180 | I've experimented with having engineering managers.
02:30:27.180 | And I can tell you, life is much better at 50, 60 people when none of those individuals or none of those roles.
02:30:34.720 | It's never about the individuals.
02:30:35.800 | It's about the roles.
02:30:37.000 | None of those roles are in your organization full-time.
02:30:39.920 | Occasionally, you need a manager.
02:30:41.980 | Occasionally, you need a lawyer.
02:30:44.700 | I can play the role of manager occasionally.
02:30:47.580 | Fine.
02:30:48.880 | And then I can set it back down to zero.
02:30:51.080 | It's almost like a cloud service.
02:30:53.480 | I want a manager service I can call on for seven hours this week.
02:30:58.060 | And then I want to take it down to zero for the next three months.
02:31:00.960 | Yeah, I read.
02:31:01.500 | I don't know if this is still the case that Basecamp is an LLC and doesn't have a CFO.
02:31:05.360 | Like a full-time accountant.
02:31:07.260 | What's actually funny is, these days, we do have a head of finance.
02:31:11.820 | We did not for the first 19 years of life, I think.
02:31:16.260 | We got away with basically just having an accountant do our books in the same way you would do a small ice cream shop.
02:31:23.320 | Except we would, over time, have done hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue.
02:31:26.680 | The scale seemed quirky.
02:31:29.440 | And at some point, you can also fall in love with your own quirkiness to a degree that isn't actually healthy.
02:31:34.440 | And I've certainly done that over time.
02:31:36.360 | And we should have had someone count the beans a little more diligently, a little earlier.
02:31:41.560 | This was part of a blessing of just being wildly profitable and selling software that can have infinite margins, basically.
02:31:48.820 | That you kind of can get away with a bunch of stuff that you perhaps shouldn't.
02:31:52.160 | What partially taught me this lesson was when we realized we had not been collecting sales tax in different U.S. states where we had nexus.
02:32:01.320 | And it took us about two years and $5 million in settlements and cleanups to get out of that mess.
02:32:07.560 | And after that, I went like, okay, fine.
02:32:09.240 | We can hire a finance person.
02:32:10.240 | Okay.
02:32:11.100 | And we now have a wonderful finance person, Ron, who actually ended up replacing something else we used to have.
02:32:16.560 | We used to have a full-time data analytics person who would do all sorts of insight mining for why are people signing up for this thing?
02:32:23.960 | And we ran that for 10 years and realized, you know what?
02:32:26.560 | If I can have either a data analytics person or an accountant, I'm picking the accountant.
02:32:29.920 | I love this so much on so many levels.
02:32:33.020 | Can we just link on that advice that you've given that small teams are better?
02:32:37.120 | I think that's really less is more.
02:32:42.900 | What did you say before worse is better?
02:32:44.700 | Okay, I'm sorry.
02:32:47.120 | Worse is better on adoption with technology a lot of times.
02:32:50.320 | Yeah.
02:32:50.560 | And I think it actually comes out of the same thing.
02:32:52.360 | It comes out of the fact that many of the great breakthroughs are created by not even just tiny teams, but individuals.
02:32:59.860 | Individuals writing something.
02:33:02.260 | And an individual writing something on some parameter, what they do is worse.
02:33:06.920 | Of course, it's worse when one person has to make something that a huge company have hundreds, if not thousands of developers that they can have work on that problem.
02:33:15.820 | But in so many other parameters, that worseness is the value.
02:33:20.260 | That less is the value.
02:33:22.500 | In Getting Real, which we wrote back in 2006, we talk about this notion of less software.
02:33:28.440 | When we first got started with Basecamp back in 2004, people would ask us all the time, aren't you petrified of Microsoft?
02:33:34.820 | They have so many more resources.
02:33:37.120 | They have so many more programmers.
02:33:39.100 | What if they take a liking to your little niche here and they show up and they just throw a thousand programmers at the problem?
02:33:45.980 | And my answer, perhaps partly because I was like 24, was first of all, no, no care in the world.
02:33:54.080 | But the real answer was they're not going to produce the same thing.
02:33:57.060 | You cannot produce the kind of software that Basecamp is with a team of a thousand people.
02:34:01.980 | You will build the kind of software that a thousand people builds.
02:34:05.680 | And that's not the same thing at all.
02:34:08.400 | So, so much of the main breakthrough in both end-user systems, but also in open source systems, in fundamental systems, they're done by individuals or very small teams.
02:34:19.000 | Even all these classical histories of Apple has always been like, well, there's a big organization, but then you had the team that was actually working on the breakthrough.
02:34:27.880 | It was four people.
02:34:28.740 | It was eight people.
02:34:29.780 | It was never 200.
02:34:31.160 | And the large team seems to slow things down.
02:34:35.820 | Yes.
02:34:36.260 | It's so fascinating.
02:34:38.160 | Part of it is the manager thing.
02:34:39.800 | Because humans don't scale.
02:34:41.960 | Communication between humans certainly don't scale.
02:34:45.340 | You basically get the network cost effect.
02:34:48.440 | Every time you add a new node, it goes up exponentially.
02:34:52.560 | This is perhaps the key thing of why I get to be so fond of having no managers at Basecamp, because our default team size is two.
02:35:01.900 | One programmer, one designer, one feature.
02:35:06.160 | When you're operating at that level of scale, you don't need sophistication.
02:35:10.740 | You don't need advanced methodologies.
02:35:14.240 | You don't need multiple layers of management, because you can just do.
02:35:18.260 | The magic of small teams is that they just do.
02:35:20.800 | They don't have to argue, because we don't have to set direction.
02:35:24.060 | We don't have to worry about the roadmap.
02:35:25.920 | We can just sit down and make something, and then see if it's good.
02:35:29.640 | When you can get away with just making things, you don't have to plan.
02:35:32.480 | And if you can get out of planning, you can follow the truth that emerges from the code, from the product, from the thing you're working on in the moment.
02:35:43.000 | You know far more about what the great next step is when you're one step behind, rather than if you try 18 months in advance to map out all the steps.
02:35:52.960 | How do we get from here to very far away?
02:35:55.240 | You know what?
02:35:56.620 | That's difficult to imagine in advance, because humans are very poor at that.
02:36:01.520 | Maybe AI one day will be much better than us.
02:36:04.360 | But humans can take one foot or put one foot in front of each other.
02:36:08.560 | That's not that hard.
02:36:09.240 | And that allows you to get away with all that sophistication.
02:36:13.780 | So the process has become much simpler.
02:36:15.740 | You need far fewer people.
02:36:17.120 | It compounds.
02:36:17.880 | You need much less process.
02:36:19.680 | You need to waste less time in meetings.
02:36:21.740 | You can just spend these long, glorious days and weeks of uninterrupted time solving real problems you care about and that are valuable.
02:36:30.500 | And you're going to find that that's what the market actually wants.
02:36:33.520 | No one is buying something because there's a huge company behind it most of the time.
02:36:38.200 | They're buying something because it's good.
02:36:39.900 | And the way you get something good is you don't sit around and have a meal about it.
02:36:46.580 | You try stuff.
02:36:47.320 | You build stuff.
02:36:48.200 | It really is kind of incredible what one person, honestly, one person can do in 100 hours of deep work, of focused work, even less.
02:36:58.420 | So I'll tell you this, I tracked exactly the number of hours I spend on the first version of Basecamp.
02:37:03.240 | And I was doing this because at the time I was working on a contract basis for Jason.
02:37:08.660 | He was paying me, I was going to say $15 an hour.
02:37:12.180 | That's what I got paid when we first got started.
02:37:13.720 | I think he had bumped my pay to a glorious 25.
02:37:15.820 | But I was billing him and I know that the invoice for the first version of Basecamp was 400 hours.
02:37:22.280 | That's what it took for one sole individual in 2004 to create an entire system that has then gone on to gross hundreds of millions of dollars and continues to do extremely well.
02:37:35.560 | One person, just me, setting up everything.
02:37:38.260 | Part of that story is Ruby.
02:37:39.980 | Part of that story is Rails.
02:37:41.160 | But a lot of it is also just me plus Jason plus Ryan plus Matt.
02:37:46.240 | That was the entire company at the time.
02:37:48.500 | And we could create something of sheer sustaining value with such a tiny team.
02:37:54.460 | Because we were a tiny team, not despite of, small is not a stepping stone.
02:37:58.700 | This is the other thing that people get into their head.
02:38:01.340 | This is one of the big topics of Rework.
02:38:04.000 | That it gave entrepreneurs the permission to embrace being a small team, not as a waypoint.
02:38:10.400 | Not as like, I'm trying to become a thousand people.
02:38:13.920 | No, I actually like being a small team.
02:38:15.720 | Small teams are more fun.
02:38:17.280 | If you ask almost anyone, I'm sure Toby would say this too.
02:38:21.540 | Even at his scale, the sheer enjoyment of building something is in the enjoyment of building it with a tiny team.
02:38:28.040 | Now, you can have impact at a different scale when you have a huge company.
02:38:32.400 | I fully recognize that and I see the appeal of it.
02:38:35.160 | But in the actual building of things, it's always small teams.
02:38:38.440 | Always.
02:38:39.040 | How do you protect the small team?
02:38:41.120 | Basecamp has successfully stayed small.
02:38:44.060 | There's been the dragons you had to fight off.
02:38:46.860 | That like, basically, you make a lot of money.
02:38:50.560 | There's a temptation to grow.
02:38:52.320 | So, how do you not grow?
02:38:54.360 | Don't take venture capital.
02:38:56.300 | Okay.
02:38:57.460 | That's step one.
02:38:58.560 | Point number one.
02:38:59.540 | First of all, everybody takes venture capital.
02:39:02.380 | So, you already went.
02:39:04.260 | I mean, that's been the answer for the longest time.
02:39:06.960 | Because the problem isn't just venture capital.
02:39:08.480 | It's other people's money.
02:39:09.760 | Once you take other people's money, completely understandably, they want a return.
02:39:14.400 | And they would prefer to have the largest return possible.
02:39:17.100 | Because it's not them sitting in the code.
02:39:19.260 | It's not them getting the daily satisfaction out of building something, chiseling, beautiful
02:39:23.660 | code poems out of the editor.
02:39:25.620 | Right?
02:39:26.140 | They don't get that satisfaction.
02:39:27.460 | They get the satisfaction maybe of seeing something nice put into the world.
02:39:30.620 | That's fair.
02:39:31.420 | But they certainly also get a satisfaction of a higher return.
02:39:33.900 | And there is this sense, certainly in venture capital, stated in venture capital, that the
02:39:39.660 | whole point of you taking the money is to get to a billion dollars or more.
02:39:43.920 | Now, the path to that usually does go through running established playbooks.
02:39:48.920 | And then when it comes to software, the enterprise sales playbook is that playbook.
02:39:54.260 | If you're doing B2B software, SaaS, you will try to find product market fit.
02:39:59.560 | And the second you have it, you will abandon your small and medium-sized accounts to chase
02:40:03.780 | the big whales with a huge sales force.
02:40:06.240 | And by then, you're 1,000 people and life sucks.
02:40:09.760 | That said, you, I mean, people are just curious about this.
02:40:13.420 | I've gotten a chance to get to know Jeff Bezos.
02:40:16.880 | He invested in Basecamp, non-controlling.
02:40:22.000 | He bought secondaries.
02:40:23.880 | So this was the funny thing is that when investing have these two dual meanings, normally when people
02:40:30.120 | think about investing, they think you're putting in growth capital because you want the business
02:40:35.680 | to hire more people, to do more R&Ds, so they can grow bigger.
02:40:39.580 | Bezos didn't do that, actually.
02:40:40.740 | He bought an ownership stake directly from Jason and I, and 100% of the proceeds of that
02:40:47.560 | purchase went into my and Jason's bank account, personal bank account.
02:40:51.860 | Not a single cent went into the account of the company because we didn't need the money to grow.
02:40:56.840 | What we needed, or what we certainly enjoyed, was to some extent maybe the vote of confidence,
02:41:04.600 | the security of taking a little bit off the table is that we dared turn down the big bucks
02:41:13.280 | from venture capitals.
02:41:14.140 | It was essentially a vaccine against wanting to take a larger check from people who then
02:41:20.060 | wanted to take the company to something enormous that we didn't want to go with it.
02:41:23.880 | So Jeff gave Jason and I just enough money that we were comfortable turning all those people down
02:41:30.840 | in a way where if it had turned belly up like six months later, we wouldn't have been kicking
02:41:36.220 | ourselves and gone.
02:41:36.880 | We had something here that was worth millions, and now we have nothing, and I have to worry
02:41:42.220 | about rent and groceries again.
02:41:44.400 | It is a vote of confidence.
02:41:45.480 | I wonder from, I'd love to hear Jeff's side of the story of like why, because he doesn't
02:41:53.020 | need like the money.
02:41:53.980 | So it's really, I think it probably is just believing in people and wanting to have cool
02:42:00.680 | stuff, be great in the world and make money off of it, but not like.
02:42:04.620 | 100% the motivation for Jeff wasn't a return because he actually has a team.
02:42:11.280 | His private office that runs these investments, who did the calculus on the investment pitch
02:42:17.380 | we gave him, which was so ridiculous that Jason and I were laughing our asses off when
02:42:22.500 | we were writing down our metrics.
02:42:24.480 | I was like, no one's going to pay this.
02:42:26.080 | No one is going to give us this multiple of this amount of revenue, and that's fine.
02:42:30.780 | I mean, we took the call essentially out of kind of an awe that Jeff Bezos even wanted
02:42:37.220 | to look at us and like, do you know what?
02:42:38.680 | We don't want venture capital.
02:42:39.520 | We don't need other people's money, but like, let's just give him a bullshit number
02:42:42.800 | that no sane person would actually say yes to.
02:42:45.320 | And then, I mean, we can each go our own way.
02:42:47.800 | And his investment team said like, Jeff, no way.
02:42:50.060 | This makes no economic sense at all.

02:42:56.760 | I want to invest in this guy.
02:42:57.820 | Because to him at the time, it was chump change, right?

02:43:08.960 | 10x that for his network than our investment did.
02:43:11.960 | Jeff seemed genuinely interested in being around interesting people, interesting companies,
02:43:18.040 | helping someone go to distance.

02:43:27.440 | vote of confidence for granted in ways that I'm a little bit ashamed of over the years.

02:43:59.480 | which we would have with him like once a year and basically just going like,

02:44:12.040 | You guys know.
02:44:12.640 | So the book was out because I'm just from a fan perspective.

02:44:22.940 | special humans in the space of tech.

02:45:02.560 | I'm playing a child's game compared to the game that Jeff is playing.
