03:36:37.060 | It's like exciting for me to just be around that because I don't, there's not many companies I've seen that in because when a company becomes successful and larger, it somehow suffocates that energy that I guess you see in startups at the early stages.
03:36:54.800 | But like, it's cool to see it at a large company that's actually able to achieve scale.
03:37:00.580 | You know?
03:37:01.780 | I think part of the secret there is that Elon actually knows things.
03:37:07.160 | And when you know things, you can evaluate the quality of work products.
03:37:11.940 | And when you can evaluate the quality of work products, you can very quickly tell who's full of shit and who will actually take you to Mars.
03:37:19.060 | And you can fire the people who's full of shit and you can bet on the people who'll get us to Mars.
03:37:24.260 | That capacity to directly evaluate the competency of individuals is actually a little bit rare.
03:37:32.140 | It's not widely distributed amongst managers, hiring managers.
03:37:37.040 | It's not something you can easily delegate to people who are not very skilled at the work itself.
03:37:45.320 | And Elon obviously knows a lot about a lot.
03:37:48.400 | And he can smell who knows stuff for real.
03:37:51.820 | And this is, at our tiny scale, something I've tried to do in the same order, where when we hire programmers, for example,
03:37:59.760 | it's going to be interesting now with AI as a new challenge.
03:38:03.380 | But up until this point, the main pivot point for getting hired was not your resume, was not the schooling you've had,
03:38:11.660 | was not your grades, was not your pedigree.
03:38:13.820 | It was how well you did on two things.
03:38:17.720 | A, your cover letter, because I can only work with people remotely if they're good writers.
03:38:22.380 | So if you can't pen a proper cover letter and can't bother to put in the effort to write it specifically for us, you're out.
03:38:29.580 | Two, you have to be able to program really well to the degree that I can look at your code and go like, yeah, I want to work with that person.
03:38:37.140 | Not only I want to work with that person, I want to work on that person's code when I have to see it again in five years to fix some damn bug.
03:38:44.160 | So we're going to give you a programming test that simulates the way we work for real, and we're going to see how you do.
03:38:50.640 | And I've been surprised time and again where I thought for sure this candidate is a shoo-in.
03:38:56.500 | They sound just right.
03:38:57.960 | The CV is just right.
03:38:59.340 | And then you see the code getting churned in.
03:39:01.880 | I'm like, no way.
03:39:02.800 | No way are we hiring this person.
03:39:05.700 | And the other way has been true as well.
03:39:07.920 | I've gone like, I don't know about this guy or this woman.
03:39:11.700 | I don't know.
03:39:13.480 | And then they turn in their code stuff.
03:39:14.980 | And I'm like, holy shit, can that person be on my team tomorrow, preferably?
03:39:19.140 | The capacity to evaluate a work product is a superpower when it comes to hiring.
03:39:23.720 | There's a step that I've seen Elon do really well, which is be able to show up and say, this can be done simpler.
03:39:31.120 | Yes.
03:39:31.480 | But he knows what he's talking about.
03:39:33.220 | And then the engineer, because Elon knows enough, the engineer's first reaction, you can kind of tell.
03:39:41.620 | It's almost like rolling your eyes if your parent tells you something.
03:39:46.240 | Yes.
03:39:46.640 | This is not, no, I've been working on this for a month.
03:39:50.600 | But then when you have that conversation a little more, you realize, no, it can be done simpler.
03:39:56.640 | Find the way.
03:39:58.200 | So there's a good, when two engineers are talking, one might not have perfect information.
03:40:03.100 | But if the senior engineer has like good instinct, that's like been battle earned, then you can say simplify.
03:40:13.860 | And it actually will result in simplification.
03:40:17.260 | And I think this is the hallmark of the true greats, that they not only have the insight into what's required to do the work, but they also have the transcendent vision to go beyond what the engineer would do.
03:40:32.340 | I think if we're looking at these rarities, obviously the myth of Steve Jobs was also this.
03:40:41.320 | Even though perhaps he was less technical than Elon is in many ways, he had the same capacity to show up to a product team and really challenge them to look harder for the simplification or for making things greater.
03:40:54.920 | In a way that would garner disbelief from the people who are supposed to do it.
03:41:00.180 | Like, this guy is full of shit.
03:41:01.340 | Like, this is crazy.
03:41:02.240 | We can never.
03:41:03.040 | And then two months later, it is.
03:41:05.120 | So there is something of this where you need, you need the vision.
03:41:10.080 | You need it anchored by the reality of knowing enough about what's possible, knowing enough about physics, knowing enough about software that you're not just building bullshit.
03:41:19.960 | There are plenty of people who can tell a group of engineers, no, just do it faster.
03:41:23.800 | Like, that's not a scam.
03:41:24.840 | It's got to be anchored in something real.
03:41:27.680 | But it's also got to be anchored in, it's a tired word, but a passion for the outcome to a degree where you get personally insulted if a bad job is done.
03:41:39.220 | This is what I've been writing about lately with Apple.
03:41:42.400 | They've lost that asshole who would show up and tell engineers that what they did was not good enough in ways that would actually perhaps make them feel a little small in the moment.
03:41:54.760 | But would spark that zest to really fix it.
03:42:00.200 | Now they have a logistics person who's very good at sourcing components and lining up production Gantt charts.
03:42:09.760 | But you're not getting that magic.
03:42:12.100 | Now, what's interesting with that whole scenario was I actually thought how well Tim Cook ran things and has run things at Apple for so long that maybe we were wrong.
03:42:21.760 | Maybe we were wrong about the criticality of Steve Jobs to the whole mission.
03:42:27.680 | Maybe you could get away with not having it.
03:42:29.320 | I think the bill was just going to come later and now it has.
03:42:33.380 | Apple is failing in all these ways that someone who would blow up Steve's ghost and really exalt him would say like, see, this is what's happening now.
03:42:44.120 | So the other thing here, too, of course, is it's impossible to divorce like your perception of what's a critical component of the system and the messy reality of a million different moving parts in the reality of life.
03:42:56.860 | And you should be skeptical about your own analysis and your own thesis at all time.
03:43:01.380 | Since you mentioned Apple, have to ask somebody on the Internet submitted the question.
03:43:08.000 | Does DHH still hate Apple?
03:43:12.100 | I believe the question is.
03:43:14.460 | So there was a time when Basecamp went to war with Apple over the 30 percent.
03:43:22.140 | What's can you tell the saga of that battle?
03:43:24.840 | Yes.
03:43:26.080 | But first, I'll tell you I fell in love with Apple, which was all the way back in also early 2000s when Microsoft was dominating the industry in a way we now see Apple and Google dominate mobile phones.
03:43:42.800 | Microsoft was just everything when it came to personal computers.
03:43:45.640 | And I really did not like the Microsoft of the 90s.
03:43:48.560 | The Microsoft of the 90s was the cutoff, the air supply to Netscape kind of characters, was the Bill Gates sitting defiant in an interview with the DOJ asking about what the definition of what is.
03:44:02.700 | And just overall unpleasant, I think.
03:44:06.480 | You can have respect for what was achieved, but I certainly didn't like it.
03:44:10.180 | And as we've talked about, I came begrudgingly to the PC after Commodore fell apart and I couldn't continue to use the Amiga.
03:44:17.280 | So I already had a bit of a bone to pick with PCs just over the fact that I love my Amiga so much.
03:44:23.700 | But then in the early 2000s, Apple emerged as a credible alternative because they bet the new generation of Macs on Unix underpinnings.
03:44:32.760 | And that allowed me to escape from Microsoft.
03:44:36.980 | And suddenly I became one of the biggest boosters of Apple.
03:44:41.040 | I was in my graduating class at the Copenhagen Business School.
03:44:45.840 | I started with the first white iBook, first person using Mac.
03:44:50.960 | And by the time we were done and graduating, I had basically converted half the class to using Apple computers because I would evangelize them so hard and demonstrate them and do all the things that a super fan would do.
03:45:03.640 | And I continued that work over many years, Jason and I actually, in I think 2004, 2005, did an ad for Apple that they posted on the developer side where we were all about Apple is so integral to everything that we do.
03:45:17.300 | And we look up to them and we are inspired by them.
03:45:20.320 | And that love relationship actually continued for a very long time.
03:45:25.160 | I basically just became a Mac person for 20 years.
03:45:29.320 | I didn't even care about looking at PCs.
03:45:32.420 | It seemed irrelevant to me, whatever Microsoft was doing, which felt like such a relief because in the 90s, I felt like I couldn't escape Microsoft and suddenly I had found my escape.
03:45:42.360 | And now I was with Apple and it was glorious.
03:45:44.360 | And they shared so many of my sensibilities and my aesthetics and they kept pushing the envelope.
03:45:48.640 | And there was so much to be proud of, so much to look up to.
03:45:51.740 | And then that sort of started to change with the iPhone, which is weird because the iPhone is what made modern Apple.
03:45:59.740 | It's what I lined up in 2007 together with Jason for five hours to stand in the line to buy a first generation product where Apple staff would clap at you when you walked out of the store.
03:46:13.960 | I don't know if you remember that.
03:46:14.980 | It was a whole ceremony and it was part of that.
03:46:18.500 | Myth and mystique and awe of Apple.
03:46:22.240 | So I just I wasn't in the market for other computers.
03:46:25.640 | I wasn't in the market for other computer ideas.
03:46:27.280 | I thought perhaps I'd be with the Mac until the end of days.
03:46:31.200 | But as Apple discovered the goldmine it is to operate a toll booth where you don't have to innovate, where you don't actually have to make anything, where you can just take 30 percent of other people's business.
03:46:44.940 | There was a lot that's crept in to the foundation of Apple, and that started all the way back from the initial launch of the app store.
03:46:54.800 | But I don't think we saw at the time I didn't see at the time just how critical the mobile phone would become to computing in general.
03:47:03.100 | I thought when the iPhone came out that like, oh, it's like a mobile phone.
03:47:06.120 | I've had a mobile phone since the early 90s.
03:47:08.220 | Well, it wasn't a mobile phone.
03:47:09.800 | It was a mobile computer.
03:47:10.800 | And even more than that, it was the most important computer or it would become the most important computer for most people around the world, which meant that if you like to make software and wanted to sell it to people, you had to go through that computer.
03:47:24.180 | And if going through that computer meant going through Apple's toll booth and not just having to ask them permission, which in and of itself was just an indignity when you're used to the Internet, where you don't have to ask anyone permission about anything.
03:47:39.720 | You buy a domain and you launch a business and if customers show up, boom, you're a success.
03:47:44.940 | And if they don't, well, you're a failure.
03:47:46.800 | Now, suddenly, before you could even launch, you'd have to ask Apple for permission.
03:47:51.760 | That always sat wrong with me.
03:47:54.060 | But it wasn't until we launched Hay in 2001 that I saw the full extent of the rot that has snugged into Apple's Apple.
03:48:04.680 | For people who don't know and will talk about it, Hay is this amazing email sort of attempt to solve the email problem.
03:48:14.060 | Yes.
03:48:14.800 | I like to pitch it as what Gmail would have been with 20 years of lessons applied in a way where they could actually ship.
03:48:22.980 | Gmail was incredible when it launched in 2004.
03:48:25.500 | And it still is a great product, but it's also trapped in its initial success.
03:48:31.760 | You can't redesign Gmail today.
03:48:34.200 | It just has way too many users.
03:48:35.760 | So if you want fresh thinking on email, I wanted fresh thinking on email.
03:48:40.240 | I needed to build my own email system and not just my own email client.
03:48:44.100 | That's what a lot of people have done over the years.
03:48:45.880 | They build a client for Gmail.
03:48:47.060 | But you're severely constrained if you don't control the email server as well.
03:48:52.420 | If you really want to move the ball forward with email, you have to control both the server and the client.
03:48:56.900 | And that was the audacious mission we set out to do with Hay.
03:49:00.040 | And that was what's funny.
03:49:02.280 | I thought our main obstacle here would be Gmail.
03:49:05.500 | It's the 800-pound gorilla in the email space.
03:49:08.740 | Something like 70% of all email in the U.S. is sent through Gmail.
03:49:13.900 | I think their world rates are probably in that neighborhood as well.
03:49:16.940 | They're just absolutely huge.
03:49:19.660 | And trying to attack an enormous established competitor like that, who's so actually still loved by plenty of people and is free, seems like a suicide mission.
03:49:34.220 | And it was only a mission we signed up for because we had grown ambitious enough after making Basecamp for 20 years that we thought we could tackle that problem.
03:49:42.040 | So I thought, hey, this is dumb.
03:49:45.080 | I would not advise anyone to go head-to-head with Gmail.
03:49:49.480 | That seems like a suicide mission.
03:49:51.380 | We're going to try anyway because, you know what, if we fail, it's going to be fine.
03:49:54.860 | We're just going to build a better email experience for me and Jason and the people at the company and our cat, and that'll be okay because we can afford to do so.
03:50:02.820 | But when we got ready to launch, after spending two years building this product, millions of dollars in investment to it, we obviously needed mobile apps.
03:50:12.420 | You're not going to be a serious contender with email if you're not on a mobile phone and you need to be there with a native client.
03:50:18.220 | So we had built a great native client for both iOS and for Android.
03:50:21.880 | And as we were getting ready to launch, we submitted both of them to the app stores, got both of them approved on, I think, Friday afternoon for the iOS app.
03:50:31.760 | And we then went live on Monday and we were so excited.
03:50:35.860 | Hey, world, we've been working on this new thing.
03:50:39.100 | I'd love for you to check it out.
03:50:40.940 | And of course, as with anything, when you launch a new product, there are some bugs.
03:50:44.520 | So we quickly found a few in the iOS client and submitted a new build to Apple.
03:50:49.280 | Hey, here's our bug fixes.
03:50:50.820 | Can you please update?
03:50:51.620 | And that's when all the help broke loose.
03:50:55.060 | Not only were they not going to approve our update, they said, oh, wait a minute.
03:51:01.280 | We gave you permission to be in the app store, but I'm sorry, that was a mistake.
03:51:04.740 | We see that you're not using our in-app payment system, which means that we don't get 30% of your business.
03:51:12.500 | You will have to rectify that or you can't be in the app store.
03:51:15.980 | At first, I thought, like, well, it got approved already.
03:51:19.540 | We're running on the same model we've run Basecamp on in the app store for a decade.
03:51:24.340 | If you're not signing up through the app and we're signing up our own customers on our own website and they're just going to the app store.
03:51:30.960 | to download their companion app, we're going to be fine.
03:51:33.820 | That was the truth, right?
03:51:35.680 | That was why I never got so fired up about the app store, even as Apple started tightening the screws, was like my business was okay.
03:51:41.800 | Now, suddenly, my business wasn't okay.
03:51:44.540 | Apple was willing to destroy hay if we did not agree to give them 30% of all the signups that came through the iOS app.
03:51:54.000 | And it wasn't just about the 30%.
03:51:56.600 | It was also about splitting and not longer having a direct relationship with our customers.
03:52:02.240 | When you sell an app in the app store, you're not selling an app to a customer.
03:52:06.440 | You're selling an app to inventory at Apple.
03:52:09.820 | And then Apple sells an app to that customer.
03:52:12.520 | That customer has a purchasing relationship with Apple.
03:52:15.460 | So if you want to give discounts or refunds or whatever, it's complete hell.
03:52:20.940 | If you want to easily support multi-platform, that's complete hell.
03:52:25.960 | If someone signs up for hay on their iPhone and they want to switch to Android, but that billing relationship, it's tied to Apple, it's complete hell.
03:52:33.920 | For a million reasons, I did not want to hand my business over to Apple.
03:52:38.000 | I did not want to hand 30% of our revenue over to Apple.
03:52:40.980 | So we decided to do something that seemingly Apple had never heard before.
03:52:45.880 | We said, no, we're not going to add the in-app payment.
03:52:50.500 | I don't care if you're threatening us.
03:52:54.040 | This is not fair.
03:52:54.980 | This is not reasonable.
03:52:55.940 | Please approve.
03:52:59.220 | And of course, they didn't.
03:53:01.100 | And it escalated.
03:53:02.280 | And after a couple of days, we realized, you know what?
03:53:05.460 | This isn't a mistake.
03:53:06.620 | This isn't going away.
03:53:07.960 | We're going to be dead if they go through with this.
03:53:11.320 | If we're not going to yield and give them the 30%, they're going to kick us off.
03:53:16.960 | Unless we make such a racket, such noise that they will regret it.
03:53:24.620 | And that's exactly what then happened.
03:53:26.280 | We were blessed by the fact that we launched Hay one week before the WWDC.
03:53:31.960 | Their worldwide developer conference, where Apple loves to get up on stage and harp on how much they do for developers, how much they love them, and why you should bill for their new devices, and so on and so forth.
03:53:43.880 | And then we also just happened to have a platform on the internet, which is very convenient when you need to go to war with a $3 trillion company.
03:53:51.660 | So I started kicking and screaming and essentially turning it up to 11 in terms of the fight and going public with our denial to be in the app store.
03:54:05.040 | And that turned into a prolonged two-week battle with Apple that essentially ended in the best possible outcome we could have gotten as David fighting Goliath, which was a bit of a truce.
03:54:16.620 | We wouldn't hand 30% over to Apple, they wouldn't kick us out of the app store, but we had to build some bullshit dummy accounts such that the app did something when you downloaded it.
03:54:28.420 | That was a rule that Phil Schiller seemingly made up on the fly when pressed for the fifth time by the media about why we couldn't be in the app store when a million other companion apps could.
03:54:38.900 | But we just happened to be able to create so much pain and noise for Apple that it was easier for them to just let us be than to keep on fighting.
03:54:47.920 | What do you think about Tim Sweeney's victory with Epic over Apple?
03:54:53.380 | I think it is incredible and the entire developer ecosystem, not just on iOS, but on Android as well.
03:55:03.620 | We owe Epic, Tim Sweeney, and Mark Rain an enormous debt of gratitude for taking on the only battle that has ever inflicted a serious wound on Apple in this entire sordid campaign of monopoly enforcement, and that is Epic's fight versus them.
03:55:22.540 | Tim recently revealed that it has cost well over $100 million in legal fees to carry on this battle against Apple.
03:55:32.780 | We, for a hot moment, considered suing Apple when they were threatening to kick us out.
03:55:37.300 | We shopped the case around with a few law firms, and perhaps, of course, they would tell us, you have a good case.
03:55:44.220 | I mean, they're trying to sell a product here.
03:55:46.580 | But they would also tell us it's going to cost a minimum of $10 million, and it's going to take five to seven years through all the appeals.
03:55:54.180 | Now, we now learned the actual price tag was 10 times higher, right?
03:55:58.360 | Epic spent over $100 million.
03:56:00.400 | It would have destroyed us to take on Apple in the legal realm.
03:56:04.400 | Only a company like Epic could do it.
03:56:06.860 | And only a company run by founders like Tim, like Mark, could risk the business in the way that they did.
03:56:17.080 | The audacity they had to provoke the fight in the first place, which I thought was just incredible.
03:56:22.160 | And to stick with it for the long term.
03:56:24.820 | No board would have signed off on this lawsuit to a professional CEO.
03:56:30.140 | No freaking way.
03:56:32.300 | So the fact that they've been able to beat Apple in also the most hilarious way possible, I think it's just incredible.
03:56:39.520 | Because remember, their first victory in the case was actually not much of a victory.
03:56:45.240 | There were about 11 counts in the trial.
03:56:49.100 | Apple basically won 10 of them, and the judge awarded Epic this one little win that Apple couldn't tell them not to link out to the internet to be able to do the payment processing.
03:57:03.600 | So they won this one little thing.
03:57:05.340 | And Apple, instead of just taking the 10 out of 11 wins and going, fine, you can have your little links, but all these other rules stay in place, decided to essentially commit criminal contempt of court.
03:57:18.760 | As they've now been referred to for prosecution.
03:57:21.680 | And angered the judge to such a degree that the rule of law in the U.S. now is that you can launch an app in the App Store and you don't have to use in-app payment, but you can have a direct billing relationship with a customer if you just link out to the open internet when you take the credit card and then hop back into the app.
03:57:41.640 | And we owe all of that to Tim and Mark.
03:57:44.780 | We owe all of that to Epic.
03:57:46.840 | We're going to launch new apps any minute now.
03:57:49.200 | I hope actually next week to take advantage of this, that revamp the HeyApps just that people who download the HeyApp off the Apple App Store can sign up in the app and can then use the web to put in their credit card.
03:58:03.520 | So we don't have to pay 30 percent.
03:58:04.920 | We have a direct billing relationship and such that they can take that subscription to Android, to PCs, whatever, without any hassle.
03:58:13.240 | And we have Tim and Mark to thank for it.
03:58:15.660 | Yeah, Tim, I mean, like you said, founders, but also specific kind of founders, because I think maybe you can educate me on this, but Tim is somebody who maintains to this day sort of the unreasonableness of principles.
03:58:31.980 | That's what I love.
03:58:32.280 | That's what I love.
03:58:32.960 | I think sometimes maybe even with founders, you can get worn down.
03:58:36.460 | It's a large company.
03:58:37.620 | Yes.
03:58:37.900 | There's a lot of smart quote unquote people around you, lawyers, and just whispering in your ear over time.
03:58:43.840 | And you're like, well, just be reasonable being, you know, this is a different thing.
03:58:47.860 | To be the sort of maintain, I mean, Steve Jobs did this, maintain, still are the asshole.
03:58:55.820 | Yes.
03:58:56.720 | Who says, no, this whole company, I'll sink this whole fucking company over this.
03:59:02.280 | That's the exact language basically I used in our original campaign.
03:59:07.200 | I will burn this business down before I hand over 30% of it to Apple.
03:59:12.760 | And that sort of indignation, that actual rage is something I try to be a little careful about tapping into because it is a little bit of a volatile compound.
03:59:21.760 | Because, I mean, I have a bunch of employees.
03:59:24.000 | We have a bunch of customers.
03:59:25.580 | It would be pretty sad if the journey of 37 signals after 25 years would come to an end because Apple would burn us down or I would burn the business down over this fight with Apple.
03:59:36.140 | But I think you also need that level of conviction to be able to even drive day-to-day decisions.
03:59:41.140 | One of the other Apple examples, I know I'm racking on Apple a little bit here, and I don't actually hate them.
03:59:46.960 | I really don't.
03:59:47.960 | I am tremendously disappointed at the squandered relationship that did not need to be sold away for so little.
03:59:57.660 | Now, I understand that the App Store toll booth is actually a pretty big business.
04:00:02.100 | It's multiple billions.
04:00:03.420 | But Apple is a trillion-dollar company.
04:00:05.620 | And I think in the lens of history, this is going to come off as a tremendous mistake.
04:00:10.440 | And I think it's already coming off as a tremendous mistake.
04:00:12.980 | The flop that was the Vision Pro was partly because Apple had pissed off every other developer.
04:00:19.440 | No one was eager to come build the kind of experiences for their new hardware that would perhaps have made it a success.
04:00:28.040 | So when you're on top and you have all the cards, you can dilute yourself into thinking that you can dictate all terms at all times and there are no long-term consequences.
04:00:37.320 | Apple is learning, finally, the fact that there are long-term consequences and that developers actually are important to Apple's business.
04:00:44.860 | And the relationship is not entirely one-sided.
04:00:46.980 | We don't owe our existence to Apple and Apple alone.
04:00:51.040 | We've built our own customer bases.
04:00:52.880 | Apple has been beneficial to the industry.
04:00:56.020 | I'm glad the iPhone exists.
04:00:57.940 | It's not that it doesn't go both ways, but Apple wants it only one way.
04:01:03.720 | And I think that is a mistake.
04:01:06.580 | And it's a mistake that was avoidable.
04:01:09.440 | And A, that's disappointing.
04:01:12.440 | Certainly disappointing for me.
04:01:13.960 | I've literally spent 20 years evangelizing this shit, right?
04:01:16.800 | I've spent so much money buying Apple hardware, excusing a bunch of things they've done over the years.
04:01:24.940 | And then for what?
04:01:28.580 | For the fact that you wanted 30% of something that I created in the most unreasonable way possible, couldn't we have found a better way to do this?
04:01:36.640 | I think they're going to get forced to do a better way.
04:01:39.820 | But did you also have to go through the indignity of having a criminal contempt charge against you, getting referred to prosecution?
04:01:47.640 | It just seems so beneath Apple, but it also seems so in line with what happens to huge companies who are run by, quote unquote, professional managers rather than founders and unreasonable people.
04:02:01.200 | Well, we should probably also say that the thing you love about Apple, the great spirit of Apple, I think, still persists.
04:02:09.200 | And there's a case to be made that this 30% of things, a slice, a particular slice of a company, not a defining aspect of the company.
04:02:16.080 | And that Apple is still on top in the hardware that it makes and a lot of things that it makes.
04:02:22.580 | And, you know, this is, that could be just a hiccup in a long story of a great company that does a lot of awesome stuff for humanity.
04:02:33.680 | So like Apple is a truly special company, we mentioned Amazon, there's no company like Apple.
04:02:39.640 | I agree.
04:02:40.460 | This is why the disappointment is all greater because we had such high aspirations and expectations to Apple that they were the shining city on the hill and they were guiding the industry in a million positive ways.
04:02:56.880 | I think, as we talked about earlier, hardware is exciting again, in large part because Apple bought PA Semi and pursued a against all odds mission to get ARM up to the level it is today.
04:03:13.280 | And we have these incredible M chips now because of it.
04:03:16.580 | And the design sensibilities that Apple bring to the table are unparalleled.
04:03:23.360 | No one has taste, certainly at the hardware level, like Apple does, even at the software level, I'd say there's a lot of taste left in Apple, but there's also some real sour taste now.
04:03:34.300 | So they have to wash that off first, I think, before they find their wear back.
04:03:38.660 | But Apple's been in a mirage before.
04:03:41.360 | I mean, Wozniak and Steve Jobs started this thing in the garage, has great success with the Apple II.
04:03:47.560 | He hands the company over to a sugar drink salesman who tanks the company into the 90s.
04:03:53.880 | He doesn't learn the lesson, spends the next 20 years building up this amazing company, then hands the company over again to a logistics person who presumably had more redeeming qualities than the first guy who put in charge, but still ends up leading the company astray.
04:04:13.080 | Now, this is the norm.
04:04:15.920 | The norm is the great companies don't last forever.
04:04:19.960 | In the long arc of history, almost no company lasts forever.
04:04:23.620 | There are very few companies around that was here 100 years ago, even fewer 200 years ago, and virtually nothing that are 1,000 years old outside of a handful of Japanese sword makers or something like that, right?
04:04:35.860 | So you can get deluded into thinking that something is forever when you're in the moment and they seem so large.
04:04:43.100 | Apple could absolutely stumble, and I think they have more reason to stumble now than ever.
04:04:49.220 | They're behind on AI, terribly behind.
04:04:51.620 | Their software quality is faltering in a bunch of ways.
04:04:56.160 | The competition is catching up on the hardware game, in part because TSMC is not an Apple subsidiary, but a foundry that services AMD and NVIDIA and others who are now able to use the same kind of advanced processes.
04:05:10.320 | This is something I learned after not looking at PC hardware for the longest time that, holy smokes, AMD actually makes CPUs that are just as fast, if not faster than Apple's.
04:05:20.220 | They're not quite as efficient yet because ARM has some fundamental efficiencies over x86, but they're still pretty good.
04:05:27.100 | So Apple should have reason to worry.
04:05:30.620 | Apple's shareholders should have reason to be concerned, not just about all these stumbles, but also by the fact that Apple is run by old people.
04:05:40.940 | Apple's board has an average age of, I think, 75.
04:05:44.680 | Their entire executive team is above 60.
04:05:48.280 | Now, that sounds horribly ageist.
04:05:51.920 | And in some ways, it a little bit is.
04:05:54.320 | In the same way, I'm ageist against myself.
04:05:56.840 | Like, I'm 45 now.
04:05:58.680 | And I sort of kind of have to force myself to really get into AI because it is such a paradigm shift.
04:06:06.120 | And a lot of people, when they reach a certain age, are just happy to stay with what they know.
04:06:10.620 | They don't want to go back to being a beginner.
04:06:12.440 | They don't want to go back to having to relearn everything.
04:06:15.140 | And I think like, this is a little hard for me at 45.
04:06:18.640 | How the hell do you do that at 75?
04:06:20.760 | I have to come back to it.
04:06:23.560 | You mentioned it earlier.
04:06:24.540 | You're a parent.
04:06:27.140 | Can you speak to the impact that becoming a father has had on your life?
04:06:31.880 | I think what's funny about fatherhood is that, for me, I wasn't even sure it's something I wanted.
04:06:37.260 | It took meeting the right woman and letting her convince me that this was the right idea before we even got started.
04:06:49.660 | I didn't have starting my own family on the list of priorities in my late 20s or even early 30s.
04:06:56.660 | It was really the impetus of meeting my wife, Jamie, and her telling me, this is what I want.
04:07:06.340 | I want to have a family.
04:07:08.660 | I want to get married.
04:07:09.740 | I want to have kids.
04:07:11.300 | I want to have three.
04:07:12.240 | And me going for a second, like, whoa, whoa, whoa.
04:07:17.960 | And then, all right, let's do it.
04:07:23.700 | And I think that's the kind of happy accident where some parts of my life have been very driven, where I knew exactly what I wanted and how to push forward to it and what the payoff was going to be.
04:07:37.620 | But when it comes to having a family, that always felt like a very fuzzy, abstract idea that, sure, someday, maybe.
04:07:48.660 | And then it became very concrete because I met a woman who knew what she wanted.
04:07:53.580 | And looking back on it now, it almost seems crazy.
04:08:02.460 | Like, there's this fork in the road of reality where if that hadn't happened and I had been sitting here now not being a father, not having a family, the level of regret, knowing what I know now about the joys of having that family would have been existential.
04:08:24.480 | That would have been, I don't know if they would have been devastating.
04:08:28.880 | I think men have a little bit of a longer window to pursue these things than women do.
04:08:35.100 | There are just certain biological facts.
04:08:37.500 | But ending up with the family I have now, ending up with my three boys, have been just a transformative experience in the sense that here's something that turned out to be the most important thing.
04:08:53.300 | And it was an open secret, not even an open secret, it was an open truth through all of history.
04:08:59.280 | You listen to anyone who's ever had children, they will all say my children are the most important to me.
04:09:04.340 | Yet somehow that wisdom couldn't sink in until you were in the situation yourself.
04:09:09.240 | I find those truths fascinating.
04:09:11.680 | When you can't actually relay them with words, I can tell you, hey, Lex, what are you doing?
04:09:19.680 | Get a wife, make some kids, get a move on it.
04:09:23.960 | And these are just words.
04:09:24.980 | They're not communicating the gravity of what it actually feels to go through the experience.
04:09:29.180 | And you can't really learn it without going through it.
04:09:32.760 | Now, of course, you can be influenced and whatever.
04:09:35.360 | We can all help contribute and little sparks and little seeds can grow in your mind about it.
04:09:40.560 | But it still has to happen.
04:09:44.440 | Now that I am in this situation and just the sheer joy on a daily basis where you think your level of life satisfaction is on a scale of one to 10.
04:09:55.820 | And then the satisfaction of seeing your children understand something, accomplish something, learn something, do something, just be.
04:10:06.360 | Just goes like, oh, my God, the scale doesn't go from one to 10.
04:10:10.440 | It goes from one to 100.
04:10:12.420 | And I've been playing down here in the one to 10 range all this time.
04:10:16.760 | And there's a there's a one to 100.
04:10:20.600 | That has been humbling in a way that.
04:10:24.040 | Is impactful in and of itself, this whole idea that I thought I had a fair understanding of like the boundaries of life in my early 30s.
04:10:35.060 | Like, what is this about?
04:10:36.000 | I mean, I've been on this earth long enough now here to know something.
04:10:38.900 | And I don't know.
04:10:40.580 | I did not know.
04:10:41.640 | I did not know that the scale was much, much broader.
04:10:45.780 | And I've often talked about the joys of having kids and just seeing your own DNA, which is remarkable to me because literally that's been the pursuit of humans since the dawn of time.
04:11:00.700 | I am here today because, whatever, 30,000 years ago, some Neanderthal had the same realization that I should procreate and I should continue my bloodline.
04:11:11.340 | And that all amounts to me sitting here here now.
04:11:15.120 | But it didn't become a practical reality to me before meeting the right woman.
04:11:21.220 | And I think that that's sometimes not part of the conversation enough that there's something broken at the moment about how people pair up in the Western world.
04:11:32.840 | And it's at the source of why we're not having enough children, because there's not enough couples, there's not enough marriage, there's not a lot of these, there's not enough of all these traditional values that even 50, 60, 70 years ago was just taken for granted.
04:11:49.060 | We're in this grand experiment of what happens if we just remove a bunch of institutions.
04:11:53.720 | What happens if we just remove a bunch of institutions?
04:11:55.420 | What happens if we no longer value marriage as something to aspire to?
04:12:01.880 | What happens if parenthood is now seen in some camps as almost something like weird or against your own self-expression?

04:12:21.400 | I kind of wish that wasn't reality.
04:12:23.420 | But we're seeing that reality play out.
04:12:25.400 | While I'm sitting here in a very traditional two-parent-loving household with three children and going, this is now at the top.
04:12:37.960 | I've done a lot of things in my life.

04:12:41.940 | I've built companies.

04:12:52.580 | That the depth of that bond is something you can't appreciate before you have it.

04:14:12.800 | But it is reality.

04:27:29.620 | That's just, if I didn't accomplish what I wanted to do today, if I get to that time, it's done.

04:34:07.300 | Which is this great track about 45 minutes from Chicago.

04:34:46.980 | Like the physical sensation of driving a race car is really unique.
04:34:52.020 | And I think if you're driving a car fast, you have maybe a 2% taste of it.
04:34:59.720 | The exposure to the elements that you get in a single-seat race car, especially one like that where your head is actually out in the elements.
04:35:05.420 | You can see the individual wheels.
04:35:07.840 | And your sensation of speed is just so much higher.
04:35:11.740 | It's at a completely different level.
04:35:13.240 | So can you actually speak to that?
04:35:14.560 | So even at that Mazda, so you can feel what can you feel like the track reverberating?
04:35:22.300 | You feel the grip?
04:35:23.280 | Not only can you see the bumps because you're literally looking straight at the wheels, you can feel all the bumps because you're running a slick tire.
04:35:31.760 | It's a really stiff setup.
04:35:32.860 | It's nothing like taking a fast street car out on a racetrack and trying to drive it a little bit around.
04:35:37.580 | So can you feel like the slipping?
04:35:39.240 | You can feel the slipping.
04:35:40.500 | That's a huge part of the satisfaction of driving a race car is driving it at the edge of adhesion, as we call it, where the car is actually sliding a little bit.
04:35:51.180 | A couple of percent slip angle is the fastest way to drive a race car.
04:35:54.480 | You don't want to slide too much.
04:35:55.540 | That looks great.
04:35:56.280 | Lots of smoke, but it's not fast.
04:35:58.140 | How you want to drive it is just at the limit of adhesion where you're rotating the car as much as your tires can manage and then slightly more than that.
04:36:08.480 | And playing at it, keeping it just at that level, because when you're at the level of or at the limit of adhesion, you're essentially just a tiny movement away from spinning out.
04:36:20.120 | I mean, it doesn't take much.
04:36:21.800 | Then the car starts rotating.
04:36:23.100 | Once it starts rotating, you lose grip and you're going for the wall.
04:36:26.900 | That balance of danger and skill is what's so intoxicating.
04:36:33.600 | And it's so much better than racing video games, too, because the criticality is taking up two notches.
04:36:40.560 | I often think about people who really like gambling, where I think, like, aren't you just playing poker?
04:36:45.280 | And like, no, the point is not poker.
04:36:48.700 | Poker may be part of it, but the point is that I could lose my house, right?
04:36:52.100 | Like, that's the addiction that some people get to gambling, that there's something real on the line.
04:36:57.900 | When you're in a race car, there's something very real on the line.
04:37:01.260 | If you get it wrong, at the very least, you're going to spin out and probably hit a wall and it's going to be expensive.
04:37:08.780 | At the very worst, you're not getting out alive.
04:37:12.460 | And even if modern race cars have gotten way safer than they used to be, there is that element of danger that's real, that there are people who still get seriously hurt or even killed in a race car.
04:37:24.860 | It's mercifully rare compared to what it used to be when those maniacs in the 60s would do Formula One and whatever, 13% of the grid wouldn't make it to the end of the year because they'd just die in a fiery, flaming fireball.
04:37:41.260 | There's still some of it there, and I think that sense that there's something on the line really contributes to it.
04:37:48.320 | But it's more than that.
04:37:49.140 | There's just a physical sensation.
04:37:50.600 | There's activation of all your forces.
04:37:52.180 | There's the flow.
04:37:54.540 | And I think that really cements, like, why I got addicted because I always, I love that flow I got out of programming.
04:38:02.340 | But getting flow out of programming is a very inconsistent process.
04:38:05.880 | I can't just sit down in front of a keyboard and go like, all right, let's get the flow going.
04:38:11.500 | It doesn't happen like that.
04:38:13.260 | The problem has to be just right.
04:38:14.760 | It has to meet my skills in just the right moment.
04:38:16.620 | It's a bit of a lottery.
04:38:18.160 | In a race car, it's not a lottery at all.
04:38:20.620 | You sit down in that car, you turn the ignition, you go out on track, and I get flow virtually guaranteed.
04:38:27.380 | Because you need, or I need, at least 100% of my brain processing power to be able to go at the speed I go without crashing.
04:38:36.200 | So there's no time to think about dinner tonight or the meeting next week or product launch.
04:38:43.860 | It just, it's completely zen in actually the literal sense of the word.
04:38:48.920 | I think of someone who's really good at meditation.
04:38:51.180 | That's probably kind of state they get into.
04:38:53.460 | It's just clear you're in the now.
04:38:55.780 | There's nothing but you and the next corner.
04:38:58.460 | That's a really addictive experience.
04:39:01.460 | So after I've had that, I couldn't get enough.
04:39:03.960 | I just, I kept going to the track every opportunity I got.
04:39:06.780 | Every single weekend for about four years, I would go to the track.
04:39:10.360 | And by the end of that time, I'd finally worked up enough skill and enough success with the company that I could afford to go, quote unquote, real racing.
04:39:18.660 | So I started doing that.
04:39:20.940 | I started driving these Porsches.
04:39:22.200 | And then as soon as I got into that, as soon as I got into, quote unquote, real competition, I was like, I wonder how far you can take this.
04:39:28.740 | And it didn't take that long before I decided, you know what?
04:39:32.260 | I could take this all the way.
04:39:34.080 | My great hero in racing is Tom Christensen.
04:39:37.240 | Fellow Dane, the Mr. Le Mans, as they call him.
04:39:41.760 | The greatest endurance race in the world.
04:39:43.360 | The 24 hours of Le Mans has been won more times than any other by Tom Christensen.
04:39:48.280 | He won the race nine times.
04:39:51.560 | So Tom just really turned me on to Le Mans.
04:39:55.900 | I've been watching Le Mans since I think the 80s.
04:39:59.320 | I have my earliest memories of watching that on TV.
04:40:01.660 | The race has been going since, I think, the 20s.
04:40:04.820 | But in the 80s, I got kind of into it.
04:40:06.860 | And then in the late 90s, early 2000s, when Tom started winning, I, like pretty much every other Dane, started watching the race almost religiously.
04:40:16.280 | So I thought, you know what?
04:40:17.140 | I want to get to Le Mans.
04:40:18.040 | And this is the magic thing about racing, that if I get into basketball, like I can't set a realistic expectation that I'm going to play in the NBA, that I'm going to go to the finals.
04:40:27.900 | Or I get into tennis and I'm going to play at Wimbledon.
04:40:30.480 | That just doesn't happen.
04:40:31.720 | But racing is special in this way because it requires a fair amount of money to keep these cars running.
04:40:36.560 | It's really expensive.
04:40:37.460 | It's like having a small startup.
04:40:39.280 | You need to fly a bunch of people around the world and buy expensive equipment and so forth.
04:40:43.260 | So you need a bunch of capital.
04:40:44.180 | And I had some through the success of the company.
04:40:46.840 | So I could do it, which meant that I could get to Le Mans.
04:40:50.360 | So I set that as my goal.
04:40:51.800 | I want to get to Le Mans.
04:40:52.820 | And I started racing in real competition 2009.
04:40:57.760 | And three years later in 2012, I was at the grid of Le Mans for the first time.
04:41:02.320 | We should say, so Le Mans, 24-hour race, endurance.
04:41:06.700 | I mean, this is insane.
04:41:09.720 | There are three drivers, mind you.
04:41:11.260 | So it's not like one guy just driving for 20 hours, 24 hours straight.
04:41:15.080 | But still, it's a pretty tough race, both physically and mentally, especially mentally.
04:41:19.680 | When you've been up for 24-plus hours, you're not quite as sharp as when you first wake up.
04:41:27.960 | And this is funny about Le Mans, too.
04:41:29.500 | It starts at around 4 o'clock in the afternoon.
04:41:31.480 | So you've already been up for half a day by the time the race starts.
04:41:34.340 | And then there's 24 hours to go before you're done.
04:41:37.180 | And you'll be in the car for anywhere from usually an hour and a half to a maximum of four hours.
04:41:43.600 | The regulations say four out of six is the max you can do.
04:41:46.460 | I've spent perhaps two and a half hours in a single stint at Le Mans.
04:41:50.040 | It's pretty taxing.
04:41:51.640 | You're going 200 miles an hour into some of these turns.
04:41:56.140 | And there's another 60 cars on track.
04:41:59.740 | Whenever I'm in my normal category, which is the LMP2 category,
04:42:04.660 | I have GT cars, which are more like a Ferrari and a Porsche, that I have to overtake.
04:42:09.920 | And then I have these hyper cars, which is the top class, that are overtaking me.
04:42:13.420 | So you've got a lot going on.
04:42:15.060 | And you've got to stay sharp for two and a half hours straight to do that.
04:42:18.520 | That is just a guaranteed way to get incredible flow for long, long stretches of time.
04:42:24.380 | That's why you get addicted to it.
04:42:26.420 | That's why I got addicted to it.
04:42:27.600 | You've got to talk me through this video, this video of you in these LMP2s.
04:42:31.360 | This is such a cool.
04:42:32.500 | This is so cool.
04:42:34.360 | Yeah, this was probably my favorite battle of my career.
04:42:37.500 | Sure.
04:42:37.860 | And Hallmark Hansen has beat past and fights past.
04:42:41.540 | Yeah, so this is me driving against Nico Miller at the Shanghai International Circuit.
04:42:47.160 | You're on the outside here.
04:42:48.340 | I'm on the outside in the blue and white.
04:42:50.940 | And we go a whole track around with basically a piece of paper between us.
04:42:55.080 | See, down this back straight.
04:42:56.140 | I get so close to him because I want to force him over on the other side of the track such that he can't just box me in.
04:43:01.900 | And we've been fighting already at this point for basically 40 minutes straight.
04:43:05.820 | I've been managing to keep this professional driver behind me for 40 minutes.
04:43:10.020 | And he finally passes me.
04:43:11.620 | But we just keep the battle on for the whole time.
04:43:14.020 | And it really just shows both these kinds of cars.
04:43:16.360 | The Le Mans prototypes we don't actually ever touch.
04:43:19.800 | We get within about an inch and keep going around the Shanghai circuit too.
04:43:25.920 | How did you get so good?
04:43:27.640 | Like what?
04:43:29.560 | I mean, that's a fascinating story, right?
04:43:31.960 | That you are able to get so good.
04:43:34.220 | I'm pretty good for the kind of driver I am, which is called the gentleman driver, which means I'm not a professional driver.
04:43:39.640 | And like many good gentleman drivers, when we're at our really best, we can be quite competitive with even professional drivers who have been doing this their whole life.
04:43:49.260 | The difference between us and the professionals is the professionals can do it every time or more or less every time.
04:43:54.620 | So I can't be this good all the time.
04:43:56.680 | When everything is just right, I can be competitive with professional drivers.
04:44:01.180 | But that's not how you win championships.
04:44:03.820 | That's not how you get paid by factories to drive.
04:44:05.780 | You've got to be good every time you go out.
04:44:07.480 | So that's a huge difference.
04:44:08.940 | But some of it was also just, I really put my mind to it.
04:44:11.920 | By the time I realized race cars is what I want to do as my serious hobby, I put in thousands of hours.
04:44:20.060 | Have you crashed?
04:44:21.720 | What's the worst crash?
04:44:22.920 | I've had a lot of crashes.
04:44:24.340 | But thankfully, nug on wood, I haven't had any crashes where I've gotten really seriously hurt.
04:44:30.020 | Have you like wrecked the car?
04:44:31.560 | Oh, yes.
04:44:32.220 | Oh, yes.
04:44:32.940 | I've wrecked many a car.
04:44:34.220 | So what does that feel like?
04:44:35.480 | Just you wreck a car?
04:44:36.660 | Like, how do you get?
04:44:37.520 | It feels like total shit if you're in a real race and other people depend on you.
04:44:42.220 | It's not even so much the car, although it's also sometimes that these cars are expensive to repair and that sucks.
04:44:47.500 | And it feels so wasteful, in a way, when you crash some of these cars.
04:44:51.580 | But the sense that you're letting a team down, endurance racing is a team sport.
04:44:57.700 | Not only do you have your mechanics, you usually have co-drivers.
04:45:00.460 | So when I crash, I just feel like, damn it, I could have avoided this.
04:45:04.960 | Yeah, but also, you could have died.
04:45:08.000 | Do you know what's funny?
04:45:09.040 | I never think about that.
04:45:10.960 | I don't think you can because I think the moment you start thinking about being able to die, you can't do it.
04:45:17.260 | You can't go fast.
04:45:18.240 | Well, I'm sure, not to go all Carl Jung and Freud here, but I'm sure that's always present in the back of your mind somewhere.
04:45:29.160 | You're not just bringing it to the surface.
04:45:31.140 | It is in the sense that it's part of the appeal.
04:45:34.240 | It's part of the sense that there's something on the line, that this isn't just virtual.
04:45:39.180 | I can't just hit reset, restart, reboot.
04:45:42.380 | If I crash this car, we're going to be out, or we're going to be disadvantaged, or it's going to get destroyed, or I might get hurt.
04:45:49.500 | I've gotten lightly hurt a few times.
04:45:52.920 | I actually had the year we won 24 hours of Le Mans in our class.
04:45:57.560 | I've been training in this Formula 3.5 car.
04:46:03.420 | It's a really fast car.
04:46:04.840 | It's a really nice exercise to do, but it's also, it doesn't have power steering.
04:46:09.720 | So some of these race cars, especially the open seaters, they don't have power steering, which means that the steering wheel is basically directly connected to the front wheels.
04:46:18.280 | So if you crash one of those cars and the front wheels suddenly turn, you're really going to hurt your hands if you don't get your hands off the wheel.
04:46:25.900 | I hadn't raced enough of those cars to know that I had to get, or to have the instinct, to have developed the instinct that I had to get my hands off the wheel.
04:46:32.900 | So I didn't.
04:46:34.020 | And I really hurt my hand.
04:46:35.520 | And this was just, I think, a month before the 24 hours of Le Mans.
04:46:39.300 | So I thought, oh, man, I'm going to have to miss it this year.
04:46:41.500 | I had like, not a cast.
04:46:43.240 | It was just seriously sprained.
04:46:44.320 | And then somehow, miraculously, like a week before the event, I was like, oh, yeah, actually, it's okay now.
04:46:50.480 | So got to do it.
04:46:51.540 | And that would have been grave regret if I would have seen my team go on to win the race and I would have to sit on the sidelines.
04:46:59.320 | But I really have been quite fortunate in the sense that most of my crashes have just been expensive or sporting inconvenient.
04:47:07.740 | They've never been something where I got seriously hurt.
04:47:10.960 | But I've seen plenty of people who have.
04:47:12.880 | In fact, my co-driver this year, and for several years, Petro Fittipaldi, drove a race car at Spa.
04:47:20.800 | Spa is one of the great racetracks of all time.
04:47:24.600 | And it has this iconic corner called Arouge, which is probably the most famous corner in all of motorsports.
04:47:29.920 | It has a great compression before you climb uphill.
04:47:34.080 | It's an extremely fast, very difficult corner.
04:47:36.840 | And just as he does the compression, his car basically sets out and he loses his power steering.
04:47:42.580 | And he drives straight into the wall and breaks both his legs and basically face the prospect that maybe his career was over.
04:47:49.240 | I've had other teammates and people I know have serious injuries that's really hurt them.
04:47:56.660 | And yet what's funny, as you say, you'd think that would sink in.
04:48:00.540 | The year before we won in 2014, that same car had a Danish driver in it at Le Mans at the race I was driving who died.
04:48:12.500 | He lost control of the car when there was a bit of rain on the track.
04:48:19.640 | And the track went unfortunately designed in such a poor way that there was a very big tree right behind the railing.
04:48:26.600 | And he hit that tree at full speed, pulled 90 Gs and was dead on the spot, which was just such an extremely awful experience to go through.
04:48:41.480 | I finished second that year, which should have been cause for a bunch of celebration.
04:48:46.040 | But it was just tainted by the fact that not only did a driver die, a fellow Dane died, a guy I knew died.
04:48:57.000 | That was pretty tough.
04:49:01.880 | So that, throw that into the pile of the things that have to be considered is the weather conditions that you mentioned of the track, the weather is dry or wet.
04:49:11.940 | It's a huge part of it.
04:49:13.800 | Even just last year at Le Mans, it was raining and I was out.
04:49:19.520 | And I hadn't made a serious mistake at the 24 hours of Le Mans since I did the first race in 2012 where I put it in the sand trap with like four hours to go.
04:49:33.120 | And we lost a couple of laps getting pulled out, but it didn't actually change anything for our result because that was just how the field was spread out.
04:49:40.680 | I'd made minor mistakes over the years, but nothing that really set us out.
04:49:43.800 | And at the race last year, when it was raining, I first clobbered a Ford Mustang when I made an overambitious pass on a damp part of the track and couldn't stop in time.
04:49:57.280 | And then felt absolutely awful as I sat in the gravel pit for two laps and knew that our race was over, a race where we were highly competitive.
04:50:06.800 | You're not blessed with a competitive car, a competitive team and competitive setup every year.
04:50:11.400 | I know how rare that is.
04:50:13.100 | So to know that we had had a chance that year and I sort of squandered it felt really bad, but that got compounded.
04:50:21.660 | I got back on track, barely made it another stint and then put it in the gravel trap again when it started raining on the entrance into Porsche.
04:50:28.940 | So this is part of why racing is so addicting too, because the highs are very, very high.
04:50:35.080 | When you win a race like the 24 hours of Le Mans, it feels just incredible.
04:50:39.480 | There's so much emotion, but if you fuck it up, the lows are very, very low.
04:50:44.200 | What are the things you're paying attention to when you're driving?
04:50:47.280 | What's, what, what is the, what are the parameters?
04:50:51.040 | What are you loading in?
04:50:52.000 | Are you feeling the grip?
04:50:56.300 | Are you basically increasing the speed and seeing what, like a constant feedback system effect it has on the grip?
04:51:03.500 | Are you trying to manage that and try to find that optimal slip angle?
04:51:08.040 | Are you looking around using your eyes?
04:51:11.200 | Are you smelling things?
04:51:13.620 | Are you listening?
04:51:14.200 | Are you feeling the wind?
04:51:15.240 | Are you, are you, oh, are you looking at the field too?
04:51:20.160 | Like how, how, how'd you not hit that guy at all?
04:51:22.420 | You get close within inches, right?
04:51:24.680 | So you have to pay attention to that too.
04:51:25.980 | It's really interesting about that specific battle where we're literally a few inches apart.
04:51:30.960 | I can't fully explain it, but humans can develop an incredible sense of space where I can't see the edge of the back of my car, but I can know exactly where it is.
04:51:42.780 | I can have a mental model in my head that gives me the exact dimensions of this car so that I can run within a few inches of a competitor car or within a few inches of the wall and not hit either when things go well.
04:51:56.800 | The car is about two meters wide and it's quite long, five meters and you can't see everything.
04:52:02.980 | The mirrors are actually kind of shit.
04:52:04.660 | There's no rear view mirror in these cars.
04:52:06.560 | You can't see out the back.
04:52:07.460 | You can only see through your two side mirrors, but you form this intuitive mental model when
04:52:13.500 | you get good enough at this.
04:52:14.500 | But what I actually pay attention to most is I run a program.
04:52:19.320 | What I try to do when I go to a racetrack is I try to load up the best program I know how for every single corner.
04:52:26.460 | What's my break point?
04:52:27.840 | What's my acceleration point?
04:52:29.840 | What's my brake trailing curve?
04:52:33.580 | And I try to pick up that program in part just by finding it myself and how fast I can go, but even more so than that, by copying my professional competitors or not competitors, co-drivers.
04:52:44.500 | So I usually always race with a pro and modern race cars produce an absolute enormous amount of data and you can analyze all that data after each outing.
04:52:54.640 | You can see an exact trace of how much you push the brake pedal, how much you did in terms of steering inputs, when you got on the gas.
04:53:02.920 | You can see every millisecond you're losing is evident in those charts.
04:53:08.440 | So what I try to do is I try to look at the chart and then I try to load that in and like that's what I got to do.
04:53:14.600 | Oh, in this corner 17, I actually I have to be 10 bar lighter on the brake.
04:53:20.420 | So I try to load that program in and then I try to repeat it.
04:53:23.780 | Now, then there are all the things that changes.
04:53:25.300 | Your tires change quite a lot.
04:53:28.140 | These tires are made to only last 40 minutes in many cases.
04:53:32.700 | Sometimes at Le Mans we can go longer, but at some racetracks they'll last as little as 40 minutes before they really fall off.
04:53:39.540 | So you got to manage that, that the grip is constantly changing.
04:53:42.100 | So your program have to suddenly fit those changing circumstances.
04:53:45.400 | And then in endurance racing, you're constantly interacting with other cars because you're passing slower classes or you're getting passed by a faster class.
04:53:52.420 | So that's part of the equation.
04:53:54.180 | And then you're trying to dance the car around the limit of adhesion.
04:53:58.840 | So you got all those factors playing at the same time.
04:54:01.220 | But above all else for me is to try to become a robot.
04:54:05.940 | Like, how can I repeat this set of steps exactly as I'm supposed to for two and a half hours straight without making 100 milliseconds worth of mistakes?
04:54:18.120 | Yeah, low latency algorithm.
04:54:19.420 | That's really a huge part of it, actually.
04:54:22.080 | Your latency is enormously important in terms of being able to catch when the car starts slipping.
04:54:29.420 | You get this sensation in your body that the G-forces are a little off, the slip angle is a little off, and then you have to counter steer.
04:54:38.000 | And obviously, the best race car drivers just feel like an intuition.
04:54:41.700 | I have some intuition.
04:54:43.140 | I don't have all of it.
04:54:44.060 | So I do occasionally spin my car.
04:54:46.460 | But that's the challenge.
04:54:47.940 | From everything you've studied and understand, what does it take to achieve mastery in racing?
04:54:54.180 | Like, what does it take to become the best race car driver in the world?
04:54:57.640 | Obsession is part of it.
04:54:59.820 | When I read and hear about Senna and the other greats, they were just singularly focused.
04:55:07.660 | Max Verstappen is the current champion of the world, and he is the same kind.
04:55:12.680 | Max has been fascinating to watch.
04:55:16.140 | I mean, he's a phenomenal race car driver, but he also literally does nothing else.
04:55:20.500 | When he's not at the racetrack, he's driving sim racing.
04:55:23.980 | He's literally in video games doing more racing when he's not doing all the racing he's already doing.
04:55:29.780 | Is there a specific skill they have that, like, stands out to you as supernatural through all that obsession?
04:55:35.980 | Like, what—is it a bunch of factors, or are they actually able to, like you said, develop a sense?
04:55:42.420 | Is it that they're able to get to the very edge of the slip?
04:55:45.460 | They're able to develop very fine-tuned sensibilities for when the car is sliding.
04:55:50.460 | They can feel just these tiny moments or movements in the chassis that transports up, usually through their ass.
04:55:57.260 | That's why you call it like a butt meter that goes up, and you feel like the car is loose, or you feel like you're just about to lock up.
04:56:06.560 | You can really hone that tuning.
04:56:09.540 | Then the other thing is you have to have really good reaction time.
04:56:13.060 | And when you look at great Formula 1 drivers, they can generally have a reaction time of just under 200 milliseconds, which is awesome.
04:56:22.100 | And even 10 milliseconds difference makes a huge difference.
04:56:25.940 | You'll see it when the Formula 1 grid, for example, they do a standing start, and you see the five red lights come on.
04:56:31.980 | And when the last light goes out, they're supposed to release the clutch and get going.
04:56:36.320 | And they can time this, so you can see exactly who has the reaction time.
04:56:40.560 | And even being off by 20 milliseconds can make the difference of whether you're in front or behind at the first corner.
04:56:47.620 | How much of winning is also just the strategy of jostling for position?
04:56:53.160 | There's some of that, and some of it is also just nerve.
04:56:55.440 | Who wants it more?
04:56:56.860 | That's exactly when that sense of danger comes in.
04:57:00.620 | There's a great quote from Fernando Alonso when he was driving at Suzuka against Schumacher, I think.
04:57:08.880 | They're coming up to this incredibly fast corner.
04:57:12.100 | It's very dangerous.
04:57:13.580 | And Alonso basically accounts, I was going to make the pass because I knew he had a wife and kids at home.
04:57:22.140 | That's so gangster.
04:57:23.160 | Just absolutely ruthless, right?
04:57:24.920 | Yeah, wow.
04:57:25.500 | That I knew he valued life more than I did.
04:57:28.040 | So there's a bit of poker sometimes in that.
04:57:31.120 | Who's going to yield?
04:57:32.560 | There's a bit of chicken race in that regard.
04:57:35.320 | And sometimes it doesn't work.
04:57:37.600 | No one yields, and you both crash.
04:57:39.360 | But very often, one person will blink first.
04:57:41.620 | Can the pass be both on the inside and the outside?
04:57:43.760 | You can pass wherever you want as long as you have just a slight part of the car on the racetrack.
04:57:50.640 | And then you just improvise and take risks.
04:57:53.300 | What a sport.
04:57:55.220 | And then Senna, of course, is like a legendary risk taker.
04:58:00.020 | Yes.
04:58:01.660 | And even before him, by the time, I mean, he died in the 90s.
04:58:06.240 | But by the time we got to the 90s, racing was already a lot safer than it was when Nicky Lauda raced in the 60s.
04:58:14.820 | That level of danger is no longer there.
04:58:17.040 | There's still just a remnant of it, and it is still dangerous, but nothing like that.
04:58:21.180 | And it's a little hard to compare through the ages, like who's the greatest driver of all time.
04:58:25.980 | I think there's a fair argument that Senna is, but we don't have the data.
04:58:30.360 | We don't know who he was up against.
04:58:31.500 | Like, how would he fare if we pitted him against Max Verstappen today?
04:58:34.660 | I do think sometimes that you can have a bit of a nostalgia for the all-time greats, but the world moves forward and new records are being set all the time.
04:58:43.520 | And the professionalism keeps improving.
04:58:45.460 | Sometimes to the detriment of the sport, I think, there's a lot of professional drivers who are not only just very good at driving, but are very good at being corporate spokespeople.
04:58:54.400 | And it used to be quite different.
04:58:56.160 | There used to be more characters in racing that had a bit more personality that they were allowed to shine because there weren't a billion sponsorships on the line that they were afraid to lose.
04:59:05.600 | Ridiculous question.
04:59:06.900 | What's the greatest car ever made?

05:01:00.560 | This is why I love having this car in Spain because they're a little more relaxed.

05:02:41.120 | were driving up to 200 miles an hour.

05:06:25.160 | is so funny because, I mean, I've been programming for a long time.

05:12:06.820 | in whatever time it takes to refresh the screen, probably five milliseconds,

05:13:31.200 | Yes, TextMate.

05:13:43.740 | One, I helped birth into this world.
